abstract: α-Synuclein is one of the major components of intracellular fibrillary aggregates in the brains of a subset of neurodegenerative disorders, including Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, multiple system atrophy, and Hallervorden-Spatz disease, which are referred to as α-synucleinopathies. We have shown previously (Fujiwara, H., Hasegawa, M., Dohmae, N., Kawashima, A., Masliah, E., Goldberg, M. S., Shen, J., Takio, K., and Iwatsubo, T. (2002) Nat. Cell Biol. 4, 160–164) that α-synuclein deposited in synucleinopathy brains is extensively phosphorylated at Ser-129 and migrates at 15 kDa. Here we examined the biochemical characteristics of the additional, higher molecular mass species of phosphorylated α-synuclein-positive polypeptides that also are recovered in the Sarkosyl-insoluble fraction of synucleinopathy and migrate at about 22 and 29 kDa. These 22 and 29 kDa bands were positive for three different anti-ubiquitin antibodies and comigrated perfectly with in vitro ubiquitinated α-synuclein that may correspond to mono- and diubiquitinated α-synuclein, respectively. Furthermore, cyanogen bromide cleavage of the 22 and 29 kDa polypeptides shifted the mobility to 19 and 26 kDa, respectively, and they retained immunoreactivity for both ubiquitin and α-synuclein. Finally, protein sequence analysis showed that the 19 kDa band contained two amino-terminal sequences of α-synuclein and ubiquitin. These results strongly suggest that phosphorylated α-synuclein is targeted to mono- and diubiquitination in synucleinopathy brains, which may have implications for mechanisms of these diseases. α-Synuclein is one of the major components of intracellular fibrillary aggregates in the brains of a subset of neurodegenerative disorders, including Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, multiple system atrophy, and Hallervorden-Spatz disease, which are referred to as α-synucleinopathies. We have shown previously (Fujiwara, H., Hasegawa, M., Dohmae, N., Kawashima, A., Masliah, E., Goldberg, M. S., Shen, J., Takio, K., and Iwatsubo, T. (2002) Nat. Cell Biol. 4, 160–164) that α-synuclein deposited in synucleinopathy brains is extensively phosphorylated at Ser-129 and migrates at 15 kDa. Here we examined the biochemical characteristics of the additional, higher molecular mass species of phosphorylated α-synuclein-positive polypeptides that also are recovered in the Sarkosyl-insoluble fraction of synucleinopathy and migrate at about 22 and 29 kDa. These 22 and 29 kDa bands were positive for three different anti-ubiquitin antibodies and comigrated perfectly with in vitro ubiquitinated α-synuclein that may correspond to mono- and diubiquitinated α-synuclein, respectively. Furthermore, cyanogen bromide cleavage of the 22 and 29 kDa polypeptides shifted the mobility to 19 and 26 kDa, respectively, and they retained immunoreactivity for both ubiquitin and α-synuclein. Finally, protein sequence analysis showed that the 19 kDa band contained two amino-terminal sequences of α-synuclein and ubiquitin. These results strongly suggest that phosphorylated α-synuclein is targeted to mono- and diubiquitination in synucleinopathy brains, which may have implications for mechanisms of these diseases. Lewy bodies (LBs) 1The abbreviations used are: LBs, Lewy bodies; LNs, Lewy nitrites; PD, Parkinson's disease; DLB, dementia with Lewy bodies; MSA, multiple system atrophy; HSD, Hallervorden-Spatz disease; mAb, monoclonal antibody; CNBr, cyanogen bromide; Ub, ubiquitin. and related neuritic changes (Lewy neurites; LNs) are the defining neuropathological characteristics of Parkinson's disease (PD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB). The discovery of point mutations in the α-synuclein gene in some pedigrees with an autosomal dominantly inherited familial PD (1Polymeropoulos M.H. Lavedan C. Leroy E. Ide S.E. Dehejia A. Dutra A. Pike B. Root H. Rubenstein J. Boyer R. Stenroos E.S. Chandrasekharappa S. Athanassiadou A. Papapetropoulos T. Johnson W.G. Lazzarini A.M. Duvoisin R.C. Iorio G.D. Golbe L.I. Nussbaum R.L. Science. 1997; 276: 2045-2047Google Scholar, 2Krüger R. Kuhn W. Müller T. Woitalla D. Graeber M. Kösel S. Przuntek H. Epplen J.T. Schöls L. Riess O. Nat. Genet. 1998; 18: 106-108Google Scholar), together with the identification of α-synuclein as the major component of abnormal filaments in LBs and LNs in the brains of patients with PD and DLB (3Goedert M. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 2001; 11: 343-351Google Scholar, 4Spillantini M.G. Schmidt M.L. Lee V.M.-Y. Trojanowski J.Q. Jakes R. Goedert M. Nature. 1997; 388: 839-840Google Scholar, 5Baba M. Nakajo S. Tu P.-H. Tomita T. Nakaya K. Lee V.M.-Y. Trojanowski J.Q. Iwatsubo T. Am. J. Pathol. 1998; 152: 879-884Google Scholar, 6Irizarry M.C. Growdon W. Gomez-Isla T. Newell K. George J.M. Clayton D.F. Hyman B.T. J. Neuropathol. Exp. Neurol. 1998; 57: 334-337Google Scholar), strongly implicated α-synuclein in the pathogenesis of these neurodegenerative disorders. Immunohistochemical and biochemical studies using anti-α-synuclein antibodies revealed that α-synuclein is deposited in other types of filamentous inclusions, including glial or neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions in multiple system atrophy (MSA) (7Wakabayashi K. Yoshimoto M. Tsuji S. Takahashi H. Neurosci. Lett. 1998; 249: 180-182Google Scholar, 8Spillantini M.G. Crowther R.A. Jakes R. Cairns N.J. Lantos P.L. Goedert M. Neurosci. Lett. 1998; 251: 205-208Google Scholar, 9Tu P.-H. Galvin J.E. Baba M. Giasson B. Tomita T. Leight S. Nakajo S. Iwatsubo T. Trojanowski J.Q. Lee V.M.-Y. Ann. Neurol. 1998; 44: 415-422Google Scholar), Lewy body-like inclusions, and dystrophic neurites in Hallervorden-Spatz disease (HSD) (10Arawaka S. Saito Y. Murayama S. Mori H. Neurology. 1998; 51: 887-889Google Scholar, 11Wakabayashi K. Fukushima T. Koide R. Horikawa Y. Hasegawa M. Watanabe Y. Noda T. Eguchi I. Morita T. Yoshimoto M. Iwatsubo T. Takahashi H. Acta Neuropathol. 2000; 99: 331-336Google Scholar), leading to the collective nomenclature of “α-synucleinopathies” for these disorders. Recent biochemical studies have shown that the full-length α-synuclein is deposited as abnormal filaments (9Tu P.-H. Galvin J.E. Baba M. Giasson B. Tomita T. Leight S. Nakajo S. Iwatsubo T. Trojanowski J.Q. Lee V.M.-Y. Ann. Neurol. 1998; 44: 415-422Google Scholar, 12Spillantini M.G. Crowther R.A. Jakes R. Hasegawa M. Goedert M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 6469-6473Google Scholar), which are recovered in detergent (i.e. Triton X and Sarkosyl)-insoluble fractions of brains of patients with synucleinopathy but not in control brains (13Dickson D.W. Liu W.-K. Hardy J. Farrer M. Mehta N. Uitti R. Mark M. Zimmerman T. Golbe L. Sage J. Sima A. D'Amato C. Albin R. Gilman S. Yen S.-H. Am. J. Pathol. 1999; 155: 1241-1251Google Scholar, 14Culvenor J.G. McLean C.A. Cutt S. Campbell B.C.V. Maher F. Jäkälä P. Hartmann T. Beyreuther K. Masters C.L. Li Q.-X. Am. J. Pathol. 1999; 155: 1173-1181Google Scholar, 15Miake H. Mizusawa H. Iwatsubo T. Hasegawa M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19213-19219Google Scholar). We and others have shown that insoluble α-synuclein from synucleinopathic brains as well as in vitro assembled filaments from recombinant α-synuclein are highly resistant to proteinase K, leaving the middle portion of α-synuclein as the core structure of the filaments (15Miake H. Mizusawa H. Iwatsubo T. Hasegawa M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19213-19219Google Scholar, 16Giasson B.I. Murray I.V.J. Trojanowski J.Q. Lee V.M.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 2380-2386Google Scholar). We have further shown by mass spectrometry and specific antibodies that the α-synuclein deposited in DLB brains as well as other synucleinopathies is phosphorylated at Ser-129 (17Fujiwara H. Hasegawa M. Dohmae N. Kawashima A. Masliah E. Goldberg M.S. Shen J. Takio K. Iwatsubo T. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 160-164Google Scholar). Quantitative immunoblot analyses have further shown that >90% of the insoluble α-synuclein in DLB brains is phosphorylated, whereas ∼4% of normal α-synuclein is phosphorylated at Ser-129, suggesting that the extensive phosphorylation of α-synuclein is a pathological event (17Fujiwara H. Hasegawa M. Dohmae N. Kawashima A. Masliah E. Goldberg M.S. Shen J. Takio K. Iwatsubo T. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 160-164Google Scholar). Additional post-translational modifications of α-synuclein, including tyrosine nitration (18Giasson B.I. Duda J.E. Murray I.V. Chen Q. Souza J.M. Hurtig H.I. Ischiropoulos H. Trojanowski J.Q. Lee V.M.-Y. Science. 2000; 290: 985-989Google Scholar) orO-glycosylation (19Shimura H. Schlossmacher M.G. Hattori N. Frosch M.P. Trockenbacher A. Schneider R. Mizuno Y. Kosik K.S. Selkoe D.J. Science. 2001; 293: 263-269Google Scholar), have been reported in synucleinopathies and autosomal recessive juvenile parkinsonism (AR-JP), respectively. In addition to α-synuclein, immunoreactivities for a number of proteins including ubiquitin (20Kuzuhara S. Mori H. Izumiyama N. Yoshimura M. Ihara Y. Acta Neuropathol. 1988; 75: 345-353Google Scholar), neurofilament (21Goldmann J.E. Yen S.-H. Science. 1986; 221: 1081-1841Google Scholar), synphilin-1 (22Wakabayashi K. Engelender S. Yoshimoto M. Tsuji S. Ross C.A. Takahashi H. Ann. Neurol. 2000; 47: 521-523Google Scholar), parkin (19Shimura H. Schlossmacher M.G. Hattori N. Frosch M.P. Trockenbacher A. Schneider R. Mizuno Y. Kosik K.S. Selkoe D.J. Science. 2001; 293: 263-269Google Scholar), microtubule-associated protein 1B (23Jensen P.H. Islam K. Kenney J. Nielsen M.S. Power J. Gai W.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 21500-21507Google Scholar), etc. have been shown by immunohistochemistry in LBs and related structures. Among these proteins, ubiquitin has been known to be the most constantly and robustly immunopositive in LBs, glial cytoplasmic inclusions, and other related lesions together with α-synuclein. The presence of ubiquitin in intracellular inclusions in synucleinopathies suggests that abnormally aggregated or misfolded proteins are targeted for ubiquitination in these inclusions in a similar fashion to tau in neurofibrillary tangles of Alzheimer's disease (24Mori H. Kondo J. Ihara Y. Science. 1987; 235: 1641-1644Google Scholar, 25Morishima-Kawashima M. Hasegawa M. Takio K. Suzuki M. Titani K. Ihara Y. Neuron. 1993; 10: 1151-1160Google Scholar). Recently, Shimura et al. (19Shimura H. Schlossmacher M.G. Hattori N. Frosch M.P. Trockenbacher A. Schneider R. Mizuno Y. Kosik K.S. Selkoe D.J. Science. 2001; 293: 263-269Google Scholar) reported that glycosylated α-synuclein (αSp22) can be readily multiubiquitinated by parkin that functions as E3 ubiquitin ligase in vitro. However, the target protein for ubiquitination in synucleinopathy lesions including LBs has been totally unknown. Here we show immunochemical and protein chemical evidence that full-length, phosphorylated α-synuclein is one of the target proteins for ubiquitination in synucleinopathies and that these α-synuclein polypeptides undergo mono- and diubiquitination. Mouse monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) Syn102 (epitope location on α-synuclein, residues 131–140) (9Tu P.-H. Galvin J.E. Baba M. Giasson B. Tomita T. Leight S. Nakajo S. Iwatsubo T. Trojanowski J.Q. Lee V.M.-Y. Ann. Neurol. 1998; 44: 415-422Google Scholar, 26Lippa C.F. Fujiwara H. Mann D.M.A. Giasson B. Baba M. Schmidt M.L. Nee L.E. O'Connell B. Pollen D.A. St. George-Hyslop P. Ghetti B. Nochlin D. Bird T.D. Cairns N.J. Lee V.M.-Y. Iwatsubo T. Trojanowski J.Q. Am. J. Pathol. 1998; 153: 1365-1370Google Scholar), LB509 (residues 115–121/122) (5Baba M. Nakajo S. Tu P.-H. Tomita T. Nakaya K. Lee V.M.-Y. Trojanowski J.Q. Iwatsubo T. Am. J. Pathol. 1998; 152: 879-884Google Scholar, 27Jakes R. Crowther R.A. Lee V.M.-Y. Trojanowski J.Q. Iwatsubo T. Goedert M. Neurosci. Lett. 1999; 269: 13-16Google Scholar), and a rabbit polyclonal antibody 259 (residues 104–119) (5Baba M. Nakajo S. Tu P.-H. Tomita T. Nakaya K. Lee V.M.-Y. Trojanowski J.Q. Iwatsubo T. Am. J. Pathol. 1998; 152: 879-884Google Scholar) were used as immunoprobes that recognize α-synuclein in a phosphorylation-independent manner. A rabbit polyclonal antibody PSer129 specifically recognizes α-synuclein phosphorylated at Ser-129 (17Fujiwara H. Hasegawa M. Dohmae N. Kawashima A. Masliah E. Goldberg M.S. Shen J. Takio K. Iwatsubo T. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 160-164Google Scholar). The mouse mAbs 1510 (28Shaw G. Chau V. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2854-2858Google Scholar) and 5-25 (29Galloway P.G. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Perry G. J. Neuropathol. Exp. Neurol. 1988; 47: 654-663Google Scholar) and the rat mAb DF2 (24Mori H. Kondo J. Ihara Y. Science. 1987; 235: 1641-1644Google Scholar) specifically recognize ubiquitin. Frozen cortical tissues from the following autopsied cases were used: three cases of DLB (neocortical form with abundant cortical LBs, stage 5 (30McKeith I.G. Galasko D. Kosaka K. Perry E.K. Dickson D.W. Hansen L.A. Salmon D.P. Lowe J. Mirra S.S. Byrne E.J. Lennox G. Quinn N.P. Edwardson J.A. Ince P.G. Bergeron C. Burns A. Miller B.L. Lovestone S. Collerton D. Jansen E.N. Ballard C. de Vos R.A. Wilcock G.K. Jellinger K.A. Perry R.H. Neurology. 1996; 47: 1113-1124Google Scholar), 79 year-old male, 73 year-old male, and a 71 year-old female), two cases of HSD with severe cerebral atrophy and abundant α-synuclein-positive dystrophic neurites (a 39 year-old male (11Wakabayashi K. Fukushima T. Koide R. Horikawa Y. Hasegawa M. Watanabe Y. Noda T. Eguchi I. Morita T. Yoshimoto M. Iwatsubo T. Takahashi H. Acta Neuropathol. 2000; 99: 331-336Google Scholar) and a 29 year-old male), one case of MSA with abundant glial cytoplasmic inclusions in cerebral white matter as well as in the brainstem and cerebellum (73 year-old female (31Piao Y.-S. Hayashi S. Hasegawa M. Wakabayashi K. Yamada M. Yoshimoto M. Ishikawa A. Iwatsubo T. Takahashi T. Acta Neuropathol. 2001; 101: 285-293Google Scholar)), and one control individual (61 year-old male). Sarkosyl-insoluble α-synuclein was prepared as described (15Miake H. Mizusawa H. Iwatsubo T. Hasegawa M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19213-19219Google Scholar, 17Fujiwara H. Hasegawa M. Dohmae N. Kawashima A. Masliah E. Goldberg M.S. Shen J. Takio K. Iwatsubo T. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 160-164Google Scholar) with slight modifications. Briefly, frozen brain tissues from patients with DLB, MSA, and HSD as well as from control individuals were homogenized in a 10-fold volume of buffer A (10 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 1 mm EGTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 10% sucrose) and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm (23,000 × g) for 15 min. The pellets were then extracted in buffer A containing 1% Triton X-100 and centrifuged at 386,000 × g for 20 min. The resultant pellets were subsequently homogenized in buffer A containing 1% Sarkosyl, incubated at room temperature for 1 h, and centrifuged at 386,000 ×g for 20 min. The Sarkosyl-insoluble pellets were solubilized in 2% SDS, spun at 23,000 × g for 10 min, and the supernatants were separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by immunoblotting. In vitro ubiquitination of α-synuclein was performed according to the same methods described previously (32Hershko A. Heller H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1985; 128: 1079-1086Google Scholar) with minor modifications. Briefly, 20 μg of human recombinant α-synuclein and 2 μg of ubiquitin (derived from bovine blood cells) or methylated ubiquitin were incubated with a ubiquitin ligase fraction (Fraction II) from rabbit reticulocytes at 37 °C for 2 h in a buffer containing 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH9.0), 2 mm ATP, 5 mmMgCl2, and 1 mm dithiothreitol. The conjugation reaction was stopped by boiling the samples in an equal volume of SDS sample buffer followed by separation of the components by SDS-PAGE. The Sarkosyl-insoluble pellets from control, DLB, MSA, and HSD brains were dissolved in 70% formic acid and treated with 2% CNBr at room temperature for 18 h. The samples were diluted with distilled water, lyophilized, resolved in SDS sample buffer, and separated by SDS-PAGE. SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting were performed as described (15Miake H. Mizusawa H. Iwatsubo T. Hasegawa M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19213-19219Google Scholar). The Sarkosyl-insoluble pellet from a MSA brain was suspended in 8 m urea, centrifuged at 386,000 ×g for 20 min, and the supernatant was subjected onto a Q-Sepharose column equilibrated with 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH7.4) containing 8 m urea. The ubiquitin-positive bands were eluted with a gradient of NaCl up to 0.5 m. The immunoreactive polypeptides were pooled and concentrated by lyophirization. After CNBr treatment, the polypeptides were applied onto SDS-PAGE and transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore). The ubiquitin-positive bands on the polyvinylidene difluoride membrane were subjected to amino-terminal sequence analysis with a Applied Biosystems model 492 protein sequencer. To biochemically characterize the changes in α-synuclein deposited in the brains of patients with DLB, MSA, or HSD, we sequentially extracted frozen brain tissues with Tris-HCl buffer, 1% Triton X-100, 1% Sarkosyl and 2% SDS and analyzed the solubilized proteins by immunoblotting with anti-α-synuclein antibodies. Immunoblots of Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions showed a couple of α-synuclein immunoreactive bands exclusively in DLB, MSA, and HSD, but not in control brains (Figs.1 and 2). The major immunoreactive band with an apparent molecular mass of 15-kDa on the Tris-tricine gel system was also immunoreactive with the phosphorylation-dependent anti-α-synuclein antibody anti-PSer129 and co-migrated with human recombinant α-synuclein as well as Tris-soluble normal α-synuclein anti-PSer129, as we have described previously (Figs. 1 and 2). In addition to the 15 kDa band, anti-α-synuclein antibodies detected a couple of minor bands migrating at a higher molecular mass range of 22–29 kDa in the Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions of DLB brains (Fig. 1). The 22 and 29 kDa polypeptides were observed in all the synucleinopathy brains (i.e. DLB, MSA, and HSD) examined in this study but were exclusively detected in the Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions, and the intensities of these bands apparently correlated with those of the 15-kDa band (Figs. 1 and 2). These 22 and 29 kDa bands were also immunoreactive for anti-PSer129, suggesting that the higher molecular mass α-synuclein-related polypeptides are phosphorylated. We next investigated whether the higher molecular mass bands represent α-synuclein multimers or, alternatively, they may correspond to α-synuclein with some specific post-translational modifications. Judging from the size of these polypeptides, we hypothesized that the 22 and 29 kDa bands may correspond to mono- and diubiquitinated α-synuclein, respectively. To test these possibilities, we analyzed the Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions of DLB brains with anti-ubiquitin monoclonal antibody 1510 (mAb 510). mAb 1510 strongly labeled the 22 and 29 kDa bands as well as the smearing substances at higher molecular mass ranges in DLB brains (Fig. 1), suggesting that these bands represent ubiquitinated forms of α-synuclein.Figure 2Comparison of the 22- and 29-kDa bands within vitro ubiquitinated α-synuclein. A, immunoblot analysis of in vitro ubiquitinated α-synuclein with Syn102 and 1510. Recombinant α-synuclein itself (α-Syn), ubiquitin itself (Ub), α-synuclein and ubiquitin (α-Syn+ Ub), and α-synuclein and ubiquitin with ubiquitin ligase fraction (α-Syn+Ub+Lig) were incubated at 37 °C for 2 h. Note that the ubiquitinated α-synuclein ladder bands were observed in the reaction of α-Syn+Ub+Lig with Syn102 and 1510 (arrows indicate ubiquitinated α-synuclein bands).B, immunoblot analysis of the Sarkosyl-insoluble α-synuclein from control, DLB, MSA, and HSD brains with in vitro ubiquitinated α-synuclein. Note that Syn102-positive 22 and 29 kDa bands detected in the DLB, MSA, and HSD brains aligned with mono- and diubiquitinated α-synuclein bands from in vitroubiquitinated α-synuclein, respectively.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) To examine our speculation that the 22- and 29-kDa bands represent ubiquitinated α-synuclein, we ubiquitinated α-synuclein using ubiquitin ligase fractions from rabbit reticulocytes in vitro and compared the mobilities of in vitro ubiquitinated α-synuclein on SDS-PAGE with those derived from DLB and other synucleinopathy brains. On immunoblots of recombinant α-synuclein by itself or with ubiquitin, a major 15-kDa band (corresponding to α-synuclein monomer) and a minor 29-kDa band, the latter presumably representing α-synuclein dimer, were detected with an anti-α-synuclein mAb Syn102 (Fig. 2A). Immunoblot analysis of ubiquitin itself with anti-ubiquitin mAb also showed a similar pattern with a major 7-kDa (ubiquitin monomer) and a minor 15-kDa band, the latter presumably representing an ubiquitin dimer (Fig. 2A). In contrast, when recombinant α-synuclein was incubated with ubiquitin and the ubiquitin ligase fraction, both Syn102- and mAb 1510-positive bands appeared at 22, 29, and 36 kDa (Fig. 2A). None of these bands were detected in reaction mixtures of the ubiquitin ligase fraction without α-synuclein and ubiquitin (Ub) (data not shown). Considering the molecular mass of Ub comprised of 76 amino acids, it is reasonable to speculate that these 22, 29, and 36 kDa bands represent mono-, di-, and triubiquitinated forms of α-synuclein. The 22 and 29 kDa bands (presumably mono- and diubiquitinated α-synuclein, respectively) derived from in vitro ubiquitination of α-synuclein co-migrated at positions identical to those of the 22 and 29 kDa polypeptides recovered from Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions from DLB, MSA, and HSD brains on immunoblots (Fig. 2B), suggesting that the 22 and 29 kDa bands from DLB, MSA, and HSD brains correspond to mono- and diubiquitinated forms of phosphorylated α-synuclein, respectively. Notably, the migration position of the 29-kDa α-synuclein dimer was almost identical to that of diubiquitinated α-synuclein (Fig 2A). To further characterize the ubiquitinated α-synuclein in synucleinopathy brains, we treated the Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions from DLB and HSD brains with CNBr that chemically cleaves peptide bonds following Met. α-Synuclein harbors four Met residues at positions 1, 5, 116, and 127 (Fig. 4A), and ubiquitin has one Met at the N terminus. When we treated the Sarkosyl-insoluble fraction from HSD brains that was most abundant in insoluble α-synuclein with CNBr, separated the digests by SDS-PAGE, and analyzed by immunoblotting with an anti-α-synuclein antibody 259 or an anti-Ub mAb DF2, polypeptides migrating at 19 and 26 kDa were observed instead of the 22- and 29-kDa bands (Fig. 3). The reduction of the molecular masses of corresponding bands by ∼3 kDa was almost equivalent to the sum of the N- and C-terminal portions (i.e. 5 and 24 amino acids, respectively) that were cleaved by CNBr treatment. (Figs. 3 and4) Notably, the anti-α-synuclein 259-positive but anti-Ub negative, 25 kDa band appeared after CNBr treatment (Fig. 3). This band may represent a truncated form of α-synuclein dimer derived from the 29-kDa full-length dimer, because the reduction in the molecular mass of the α-synuclein dimer by CNBr treatment (equivalent to 58 amino acids) is predicted to be larger than that of ubiquitinated α-synuclein (29 + 1 amino acids). Immunoblot analysis of the CNBr-treated Sarkosyl-insoluble pellet from an MSA brain also showed patterns similar to those of DLB and HSD brains. These results supported our view that the 22-kDa band in the insoluble fractions of synucleinopathy brains represents monoubiquitinated α-synuclein, and the 29 kDa band may be the mixture of a diubiquitinated α-synuclein and α-synuclein dimer. It is consistent with the fact that the ubiquitin-acceptable lysine residues are located in the N-terminal to middle portion of α-synuclein (residues 6–115) rather than in the extreme N- or C-terminal regions of α-synuclein.Figure 3Immunoblot analysis of the Sarkosyl-insoluble α-synuclein after CNBr treatment. A, immunoblots of the Sarkosyl-insoluble fraction from HSD brain prior to (lane 1) and after (lane 2) CNBr treatment with anti-α-synuclein antibody 259 and anti-ubiquitin antibody DF2. Note that after the CNBr treatment, 19 and 26 kDa bands (arrowheads) were detected with both 259 and DF2. A 25-kDa band (arrows) appeared after CNBr treatment was observed only with anti-α-Syn antibody 259.B, immunoblots of CNBr-treated Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions from control (Con), DLB, and HSD brains with 259 and anti-Ub antibody 5-25. The 19- and 26-kDa bands were detected with 259 and 5-25 in the DLB and HSD brains but not in control.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) To confirm the ubiquitination of α-synuclein in synucleinopathy brains, we further analyzed the ubiquitin-positive α-synuclein bands at the amino acid sequence level. The Sarkosyl-insoluble pellet from an MSA brain was extracted in 8 m urea and partially purified on a Q-Sepharose column. After CNBr treatment, the 19-kDa polypeptide was separated by SDS-PAGE, transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane, and subjected to amino-terminal sequence analysis. Protein sequence analysis showed that the 19-kDa polypeptide contained two amino-terminal sequences, KGLSKAKE and qIFvKtL (lower case letters indicate signals weakly assigned), which correspond to the amino-terminal sequences of CNBr-cleaved α-synuclein (residues 6–13) and ubiquitin (residues 2–8), respectively. This result provides protein chemical evidence that the 22-kDa polypeptide and the 19-kDa CNBr fragment are monoubiquitinated forms of α-synuclein. During the analysis of post-translational modifications (e.g. phosphorylation) of α-synuclein in synucleinopathy brains, we found two α-synuclein-positive polypeptides migrating at 22 and 29 kDa, in addition to the major 15-kDa band, which were immunoreactive to both phosphorylation-independent and Ser(P)-129-specific anti-α-synuclein antibodies. These 22 and 29 kDa bands were also immunoreactive to three different anti-ubiquitin antibodies (i.e. mAbs 1510, DF2, and 5-25). Furthermore, these bands aligned on SDS-PAGE with the in vitroubiquitinated α-synuclein bands that presumably correspond to mono- and diubiquitinated α-synuclein, respectively. The 22 and 29 kDa bands shifted to positions at 19 and 26 kDa, respectively, after treatment with CNBr, which was also immunopositive for both an anti-α-synuclein antibody 259 and anti-ubiquitin antibodies, providing further evidence that these represent ubiquitinated forms of α-synuclein. Finally, protein sequence analysis showed that the 19-kDa CNBr fragment of the ubiquitin-positive polypeptide has two amino-terminal sequences of α-synuclein and ubiquitin. These data strongly suggest that a fraction of phosphorylated α-synuclein deposited in DLB, MSA, and HSD brains is mono- or diubiquitinated. A number of immunohistochemical studies on synucleinopathy brains have shown that LBs and LNs in PD and DLB, glial cytoplasmics and neural cytoplasmic inclusions in MSA, and LB-like inclusions and dystrophic neurites in HSD are positively stained with anti-ubiquitin antibodies, although the amounts of Ub-positive structures are much less than those positive for α-synuclein (6Irizarry M.C. Growdon W. Gomez-Isla T. Newell K. George J.M. Clayton D.F. Hyman B.T. J. Neuropathol. Exp. Neurol. 1998; 57: 334-337Google Scholar, 12Spillantini M.G. Crowther R.A. Jakes R. Hasegawa M. Goedert M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 6469-6473Google Scholar). Densitometric analysis has shown that the ratio of relative intensities of ubiquitin-positive 22 and 29 kDa bands to those of a 15-kDa α-synuclein monomer in Sarkosyl-insoluble fractions from DLB brains was ∼1:10, suggesting that mono- or diubiquitinated α-synuclein may be a minor species, although the high molecular mass smearing substances or SDS-insoluble fractions may contain multiubiquitinated forms of α-synuclein. Indeed, support for this notion comes from our previous attempts to raise mAbs to LBs, which yielded an antibody (LB112) that specifically reacted with multiubiquitin chains in LBs, and this provided the first biochemical evidence that suggests a role for ubiquitination in LB formation (33Iwatsubo T. Yamaguchi H. Fujimuro M. Yokosawa H. Ihara Y. Lee V.M.-Y. Trojanowski J.Q. Am. J. Pathol. 1996; 148: 1517-1529Google Scholar). Because the mid-portion of α-synuclein harbors 15 Lys residues, further protein chemical analysis is required to locate the exact position of ubiquitin-ligated Lys residue. As to the possible diubiquitinated form (i.e. 29 kDa) of α-synuclein, it is unknown whether the two ubiquitin molecules are conjugated to two different lysine residues, or alternatively, only one Lys residue of α-synuclein is ubiquitinated and the second ubiquitin is conjugated to the initial one, forming a “T-shaped” diubiquitin moiety. It has been shown that tau in paired helical filaments of Alzheimer brains are ubiquitinated (24Mori H. Kondo J. Ihara Y. Science. 1987; 235: 1641-1644Google Scholar, 25Morishima-Kawashima M. Hasegawa M. Takio K. Suzuki M. Titani K. Ihara Y. Neuron. 1993; 10: 1151-1160Google Scholar); our previous protein chemical analysis has identified a couple of ubiquitination sites within the microtubule binding domain of tau that comprise the core structure of paired helical filaments (25Morishima-Kawashima M. Hasegawa M. Takio K. Suzuki M. Titani K. Ihara Y. Neuron. 1993; 10: 1151-1160Google Scholar). Importantly, ∼70% of ubiquitin conjugated to tau in paired helical filaments were present in monoubiquitinated form, although some multiubiquitin chains also were detected. Taken together with our previous observation that the core structure of α-synuclein filaments is composed of residues 31–109 (15Miake H. Mizusawa H. Iwatsubo T. Hasegawa M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19213-19219Google Scholar), it is possible to speculate that Lys residues within or flanking the positions of the core structures of insoluble filaments are prone to undergo ubiquitination by some specific ubiquitin ligase system that recognizes abnormally fibrillized proteins, although an effective formation of multi-ubiquitin chains is interfered with by an unknown mechanism, allowing the progressive deposition of oligoubiquitinated proteins that are less effectively targeted to proteasome degradation. Our data suggest that mono- or diubiquitinated α-synuclein in synucleinopathy brains is also phosphorylated at Ser-129. Although it is well known that protein phosphorylation triggers ubiquitination of a number of short lived proteins (e.g. cyclin or β-catenin) (34Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 425-479Google Scholar), it is unknown whether the phosphorylation at Ser-129 of α-synuclein, which is specifically up-regulated and may promote deposition of insoluble α-synuclein in synucleinopathic brains, may have some role in the ubiquitination and degradation of α-synuclein in diseased brains. Recent data suggest that monoubiquitination of a subset of proteins does not serve as a signal for proteasome degradation but instead may induce endocytosis or membrane trafficking (35Hicke L. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2001; 2: 195-201Google Scholar), although it is not known unequivocally whether this modification might play some role in the degradation of α-synuclein. It is tempting to speculate that oligoubiquitination may have some promotive effects on the deposition of filamentous α-synuclein in diseased brains. Further studies are required to clarify the relationship between phosphorylation and ubiquitination. Recently, Shimura et al. have reported that a 22-kDaO-glycosylated form of α-synuclein (αSp22) serves as a good substrate for parkin, an E3 ubiquitin ligase that is deficient in autosomal recessive juvenile parkinsonism, and is effectively multiubiquitinated by parkin in vitro. Our observation strongly suggests that the 22 kDa α-synuclein-positive polypeptide in insoluble deposits in synucleinopathy brains represents a monoubiquitinated α-synuclein and not the αSp22 species. Moreover, deposition of insoluble α-synuclein is not observed in the brains of autosomal recessive juvenile parkinsonism, where αSp22 is increased in soluble fractions. Nonetheless, our novel findings provide new insights into the intriguing possibility for a role of the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway in the deposition and degradation of α-synuclein in different types of neurodegenerative α-synucleinopathies. We thank the families of the patients studied here whose generosity made this research possible. We thank Drs. Hiroshi Mori and Yasuo Ihara for an anti-Ub antibody DF2, Dr. Inge Grundke-Iqbal for an anti-Ub antibody 5-25, Dr. Shigeo Nakajo for an anti-α-synuclein antibody 259, and Minami Baba and Akihiko Koyama for helpful discussions.

Hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) regulates the transcription of many genes induced by low oxygen conditions. Recent studies have demonstrated that non-hypoxic stimuli can also activate HIF-1 in a cell-specific manner. Here, we define two key mechanisms that are implicated in increasing the active subunit of the HIF-1 complex, HIF-1α, following the stimulation of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) with angiotensin II (Ang II). We show that, in contrast to hypoxia, the induction of HIF-1α by Ang II in VSMC is dependent on active transcription and ongoing translation. We demonstrate that stimulation of VSMC by Ang II strongly increases HIF-1α gene expression. The activation of diacylglycerol-sensitive protein kinase C (PKC) plays a major role in the increase of HIF-1α gene transcription. We also demonstrate that Ang II relies on ongoing translation to maintain elevated HIF-1α protein levels. Ang II increases HIF-1α translation by a reactive oxygen species (ROS)-dependent activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase pathway, which acts on the 5′-untranslated region of HIF-1α mRNA. These results establish that the non-hypoxic induction of the HIF-1 transcription factor via vasoactive hormones (Ang II and thrombin) is triggered by a dual mechanism,i.e. a PKC-mediated transcriptional action and a ROS-dependent increase in HIF-1α protein expression. Elucidation of these signaling pathways that up-regulate the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) could have a strong impact on different aspects of vascular biology. Recent studies have demonstrated that non-hypoxic stimuli can also activate HIF-1 in a cell-specific manner. Here, we define two key mechanisms that are implicated in increasing the active subunit of the HIF-1 complex, HIF-1α, following the stimulation of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) with angiotensin II (Ang II). We also demonstrate that Ang II relies on ongoing translation to maintain elevated HIF-1α protein levels. Ang II increases HIF-1α translation by a reactive oxygen species (ROS)-dependent activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase pathway, which acts on the 5′-untranslated region of HIF-1α mRNA. Elucidation of these signaling pathways that up-regulate the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) could have a strong impact on different aspects of vascular biology. Hypoxia activates a number of genes that are important in the cellular and tissular adaptation to low oxygen conditions (1Semenza G.L. Trends Mol. Med. 2001; 7: 345-350Google Scholar). These genes include erythropoietin, glucose transporters, glycolytic enzymes, and the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). 1The abbreviations used are: VEGF, vascular endothelial growth factor; HIF-1, hypoxia-inducible factor-1; HRE, hypoxic response element; VSMC, vascular smooth muscle cells; Ang II, angiotensin II; ROS, reactive oxygen species; PI3K, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase; UTR, untranslated region; PMA, 12,13-phorbol myristate acetate; MAPK, mitogen activated protein kinase; FCS, fetal calf serum; PKC, protein kinase C; DAG, diacylglycerol; DPI, diphenyleneiodonium; p70S6K, p70S6 kinase; mTOR, mammalian target of rapamycin; eIF, eukaryotic translation initiation factor; 4E-BP, 4E-binding protein. 1The abbreviations used are: VEGF, vascular endothelial growth factor; HIF-1, hypoxia-inducible factor-1; HRE, hypoxic response element; VSMC, vascular smooth muscle cells; Ang II, angiotensin II; ROS, reactive oxygen species; PI3K, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase; UTR, untranslated region; PMA, 12,13-phorbol myristate acetate; MAPK, mitogen activated protein kinase; FCS, fetal calf serum; PKC, protein kinase C; DAG, diacylglycerol; DPI, diphenyleneiodonium; p70S6K, p70S6 kinase; mTOR, mammalian target of rapamycin; eIF, eukaryotic translation initiation factor; 4E-BP, 4E-binding protein. VEGF is a major angiogenic factor that has been shown to activate new blood vessel formation in a number of experimental models (2Risau W. Nature. 1997; 386: 671-674Google Scholar, 3Mustonen T. Alitalo K. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 895-898Google Scholar, 4Hanahan D. Folkman J. Cell. 1996; 86: 353-364Google Scholar, 5Ferrara N. J. Mol. Med. 1999; 77: 527-543Google Scholar). Transcriptional up-regulation was shown to be implicated in the induction of this gene, an action mediated by the specific binding of the hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) to the hypoxic response element (HRE) (6Wang G.L. Jiang B.H. Rue E.A. Semenza G.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 5510-5514Google Scholar, 7Semenza G.L. Wang G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 5447-5454Google Scholar). The HIF-1 transcription factor is a heterodimer composed of HIF-1α and HIF-1β. Although the HIF-1β protein is readily found in all cells, HIF-1α is virtually undetectable in normal oxygen conditions. When cells are subjected to hypoxic conditions (1% oxygen), protein expression levels of the HIF-1α subunit are rapidly increased. Instead of acting on HIF-1α transcription or translation, hypoxia increases HIF-1α protein levels by inhibiting the rapid ubiquitination and degradation of the HIF-1α protein by the proteasome. An elegant series of studies has shown that under normal oxygen conditions, HIF-1α is modified by prolyl hydroxylation, which permits the binding of pVHL, a recognition component of the E3 ligase complex. This promotes the ubiquitin-degradation of HIF-1α. Under hypoxic conditions, prolyl hydroxylation of HIF-1α is blocked, and the HIF-1 transcription factor is stabilized (8Maxwell P.H. Wiesener M.S. Chang G.W. Clifford S.C. Vaux E.C. Cockman M.E. Wykoff C.C. Pugh C.W. Maher E.R. Ratcliffe P.J. Nature. 1999; 399: 271-275Google Scholar, 9Jaakkola P. Mole D.R. Tian Y.M. Wilson M.I. Gielbert J. Gaskell S.J. Kriegsheim A. Hebestreit H.F. Mukherji M. Schofield C.J. Maxwell P.H. Pugh C.W. Ratcliffe P.J. Science. 2001; 292: 468-472Google Scholar, 10Ivan M. Kondo K. Yang H. Kim W. Valiando J. Ohh M. Salic A. Asara J.M. Lane W.S. Kaelin Jr., W.G. Science. 2001; 292: 464-468Google Scholar, 11Cockman M.E. Masson N. Mole D.R. Jaakkola P. Chang G.W. Clifford S.C. Maher E.R. Pugh C.W. Ratcliffe P.J. Maxwell P.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25733-25741Google Scholar, 12Bruick R.K. McKnight S.L. Science. 2001; 294: 1337-1340Google Scholar, 13Epstein A.C. Gleadle J.M. McNeill L.A. Hewitson K.S. O'Rourke J. Mole D.R. Mukherji M. Metzen E. Wilson M.I. Dhanda A. Tian Y.M. Masson N. Hamilton D.L. Jaakkola P. Barstead R. Hodgkin J. Maxwell P.H. Pugh C.W. Schofield C.J. Ratcliffe P.J. Cell. 2001; 107: 43-54Google Scholar). We were recently the first to show that VEGF expression in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) induced by non-hypoxic stimuli like angiotensin II (Ang II), thrombin, and platelet-derived growth factor is mediated through activation of the HIF-1 complex. The HIF-1α subunit was highly elevated at the protein expression level following stimulation with the aforementioned agents, allowing activation of the HIF-1 transcription factor (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar). Our studies also demonstrated that reactive oxygen species (ROS) play an important role in the activation of HIF-1. However, the cellular signaling mechanisms that are implicated in increasing HIF-1α protein levels in VSMC after stimulation with these agents remain unclear. In this study, we demonstrate that stimulation of VSMC by Ang II strongly increases HIF-1α gene expression. The activation of the diacylglycerol-sensitive protein kinase C plays an important part in the increase of HIF-1α transcription. We also demonstrate that Ang II relies on ongoing translation to maintain elevated HIF-1α protein levels. Ang II increases HIF-1α translation by ROS-dependent activation of phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase (PI3K) pathway and through the 5′-untranslated region (UTR) of HIF-1α mRNA. These results identify two separate pathways that are responsible for the hormonal induction of the HIF-1 transcription complex. Actinomycin D, Ang II, catalase fromAspergillus niger, cycloheximide, diphenyleneiodonium chloride, 12,13-phorbol myristate acetate (PMA), and wortmannin were from Sigma. GF109203X (bisindolylmaleimide I), Ly294002, and rapamycin were from Calbiochem. Anti-HIF-1 antiserum 2087 was raised in rabbits immunized against the last 20 amino acids of the C termini of human HIF-1α (15Richard D.E. Berra E. Gothie E. Roux D. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 32631-32638Google Scholar). The monoclonal anti-phospho-p44/p42 MAPK antibody was from Sigma. The phospho-specific p70S6 kinase antibody was fromCell Signaling Technology. Horseradish peroxidase-coupled anti-mouse and anti-rabbit antibodies were from Promega. The PRE-tk-LUC reporter was from Dr. Steven McKnight (University of Texas). pHIF-1A-572/+32Luc and pHIF-1A-572/+284Luc reporters were graciously provided by Dr. Gregg Semenza (Johns Hopkins University). The antisense p22phox expression plasmid was kindly provided by Dr. Kathy Griendling (Emory University). p85ΔPI3K was provided by Drs. Masato Kasuga (Kobe University) and Jean-Claude Chambard (CNRS, Université de Nice). VSMC were isolated from the thoracic aortas of 6-week-old male Wistar rats by enzymatic dissociation (16Owens G.K. Loeb A. Gordon D. Thompson M.M. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 102: 343-352Google Scholar). Cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal calf serum (FCS), penicillin (50 units/ml), and streptomycin (50 μg/ml) (Invitrogen) in a humid atmosphere (5% CO2, 95% air). Cells were serially passaged upon reaching confluence, and all experiments were performed on passages 3–10. Quiescent cells were obtained by total deprivation of FCS for 16–20 h. Pretreatment of cells with different compounds was performed 15 min prior to stimulation. Hypoxic conditions were obtained by placing the cells in a sealed “Bug-Box” anaerobic work station (Ruskinn Technologies, Leeds, United Kingdom). The oxygen levels in this work station were maintained at 1–2% with the residual gas mixture containing 93–94% nitrogen and 5% carbon dioxide. Confluent cells were lysed in 2× Laemmli sample buffer. Protein concentration was determined by Lowry assay. 25 μg of whole cell extracts were resolved in SDS-polyacrylamide gels (8%) and electrophoretically transferred onto a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Immobilon-P, Millipore Corp.). Proteins of interest were revealed with specific antibodies as indicated (1:1000 dilution for primary antibodies and 1:5000 for secondary antibodies). The bands were visualized with the ECL system (Amersham Biosciences). Confluent cells were rendered quiescent 18 h prior to a 3 h stimulation in methionine-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium. Easy Tag Express35S-protein labeling mix (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) was then added at a final concentration of 0.3 mCi/ml, and cells were labeled for 30 min and harvested in lysis buffer (50 mmTris, pH 8.0, 0.1% SDS, 1% Nonidet P-40, 5 mm deoxycholic acid, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mm dithiothreitol). Cell extracts (1 mg) were precleared with 50 μl of protein A-Sepharose followed by the addition of 3 μl of anti-HIF-1α antiserum 2087. Extracts were left overnight at 4 °C prior to the addition of 50 μl of protein A-Sepharose for 2 h at 4 °C. Sepharose beads were then washed three times with lysis buffer and resuspended in 2× Laemmli sample buffer. Samples were resolved in SDS-polyacrylamide gels (8%) followed by gel drying and exposure to Kodak BioMax MS film. Confluent cells were lysed, and RNA was isolated with TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen). RNA resolved on 1% agarose/6% formaldehyde gels was transferred to Hybond N+ nylon membrane (Amersham Biosciences) and hybridized with a radioactive cDNA probe comprising either the first 900-bp coding sequence of the human HIF-1α gene or the total coding sequence of the mouse VEGF gene. A probe against 18 S rRNA was used as a loading control. Results were quantified with the use of a Storm blot imaging system (AmershamBiosciences). Reporter (500 ng/well) was used along with cytomegalovirus Renilla reniformis luciferase expression vector (250 ng/well; Promega) as a control for transfection efficiency. Transfection of VSMC was performed using the Superfect transfection reagent (Qiagen) at a 1:5 DNA/reagent ratio. At 3 h post-transfection, cells were washed, and fresh medium was added. At 12 h post-transfection, cells were deprived of FCS for 16 h. Stimulation with Ang II and hypoxia was performed for 18 h. Cells were then washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline, and luciferase assays were performed with the Dual-Luciferase reporter assay system (Promega). Results were quantified with a Topcount NXT luminescence counter (Packard Bioscience). Results are expressed as a ratio of beetle luciferase activity over R. reniformis luciferase activity. All data expressed an average of at least three independent experiments performed in triplicate. For the HIF-1A reporters, duplicate wells were lysed in TRIzol reagent, and total RNA was extracted. Reverse transcription was then preformed using the Ready-To-Go T-primed first strand kit (Amersham Biosciences) followed by amplification by PCR of the firefly and Renilla sequences (primer sequences available upon request). Products were then electrophoretically migrated on a 1% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide. As mentioned previously, we have shown that Ang II strongly induced an increase in HIF-1α protein expression levels in VSMC (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar). In the same study, we also showed that HIF-1α induction by Ang II proceeded in a manner distinct from that mediated by hypoxia. Interestingly, when time course studies of HIF-1α protein induction were performed in VSMC following stimulation with Ang II, we noticed a striking difference between the kinetics of HIF-1α protein induction mediated by hypoxia and that mediated by Ang II. As seen in Fig. 1A, the hypoxic induction of HIF-1α was rapid, and an increase could be seen at as early as 5 min following hypoxic incubation. Maximal stimulation was attained between 1–2 h of incubation in oxygen-deprived conditions. In contrast, stimulation with Ang II caused a more latent time course. No increase in HIF-1α protein expression levels could be seen for times up to 1 h following Ang II addition (Fig. 1A). A small but detectable increase in HIF-1α protein expression levels could be observed at 1 h following Ang II addition, with maximal stimulation obtained between 3 and 4 h of incubation in the presence of Ang II. This was not due to slow receptor activation, because p42/p44 MAPK phosphorylation, a control for AT1 receptor activity, was strongly increased at the first time point (5 min). Given the slow induction of HIF-1α, these results suggest that transcriptional activity is implicated in the maximal increase of HIF-1α in VSMC following Ang II stimulation. To confirm this, we pretreated cells for 15 min with the commonly used inhibitor of transcription, actinomycin D, prior to stimulation with Ang II for 4 h. Following this treatment, the activation of HIF-1α by Ang II in VSMC was almost completely inhibited (Fig. 1B). Actinomycin D did not block normal receptor signaling, because the ability of Ang II to activate p42/p44 MAPK was not decreased. It is also noteworthy to mention that HIF-1α protein levels induced during hypoxia were not decreased by treatment with actinomycin D. Interestingly, actinomycin D treatment in hypoxia induced a marked increase in the molecular weight of the HIF-1α protein (Fig. 1B). We believe that this is due to increased HIF-1α phosphorylation in these conditions. We have previously shown that p42/p44 MAPK activity can induce a shift in HIF-1α molecular weight (15Richard D.E. Berra E. Gothie E. Roux D. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 32631-32638Google Scholar). p42/p44 MAPK activity was also increased when VSMC were treated with actinomycin D (Fig. 1B, lower panel). It is therefore possible that this increased p42/p44 MAPK activity causes the shift in the molecular weight of the HIF-1α protein. We are currently investigating this possibility. Similar results were obtained when the experiment was performed in the presence of another transcriptional inhibitor, 5,6-dichlorobenzimidazole riboside (data not shown). These results demonstrate that, in contrast to hypoxia, transcriptional activity is essential for Ang II-increased HIF-1α protein levels. Given the ability of actinomycin D to attenuate Ang II-mediated induction of HIF-1α protein expression levels, we wondered whether Ang II stimulation could increase HIF-1α mRNA levels. If this was the case, this increase would directly influence the turnover of HIF-1α protein. As mentioned previously, traditional HIF-1α inducers such as hypoxia or cobalt have very little effect on HIF-1α mRNA levels in a number of cell lines (17Wenger R.H. Rolfs A. Marti H.H. Guenet J.L. Gassmann M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 223: 54-59Google Scholar, 18Kallio P.J. Pongratz I. Gradin K. McGuire J. Poellinger L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 5667-5672Google Scholar, 19Huang L.E. Arany Z. Livingston D.M. Bunn H.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 32253-32259Google Scholar). This is also the case in VSMC, because a 4-h incubation period in hypoxic conditions did not affect the basal level of HIF-1α mRNA in these cells (Fig. 2A). However, the expression level of HIF-1α mRNA was strongly increased in VSMC stimulated with Ang II. This increase was maximal after a 4-h stimulation with 100 nm Ang II (Fig. 2B). As with the increase in HIF-1α protein expression levels, the increase in HIF-1α mRNA was mediated through the AT1 receptor subtype because the AT1-specific antagonist, losartan, completely blocked the increase in HIF-1α mRNA (Fig. 2A). PD123319, an AT2-specific inhibitor, had no effect on the ability of Ang II to up-regulate HIF-1α mRNA expression levels (results not shown). To evaluate the effect of Ang II on HIF-1α mRNA transcription, we used a luciferase reporter, pHIF-1A-572/+32Luc, driven by the humanHIF-1A gene promoter region (20Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Google Scholar). When cells were transfected with this reporter and stimulated with Ang II, a strong increase (6.4-fold over basal levels) in reporter activity was observed (Fig. 3). In contrast, hypoxia did not significantly increase HIF-1 promoter activity. These results indicate that Ang II increases the rate of transcription of theHIF-1A gene in VSMC. Studies were also performed to evaluate HIF-1α mRNA stability following Ang II stimulation. To perform these studies, we evaluated the HIF-1α mRNA degradation rate after 4 h of Ang II treatment by blocking transcription with actinomycin D in either the presence or absence of losartan, which inhibits Ang II signaling. However, no differences could be observed between the HIF-1α mRNA half-life in these two conditions, indicating that HIF-1α mRNA stability is not increased during Ang II stimulation (results not shown). Activation of PKC is one pathway by which Ang II regulates gene expression. In VSMC, Ang II potently activates a number of PKC isoforms, including the diacylglycerol (DAG)-sensitive forms of PKC. To investigate whether these PKCs are implicated in the regulation of HIF-1α mRNA, we treated VSMC with PMA. As seen in Fig. 4A, PMA strongly increased HIF-1α protein expression levels in VSMC. This increase was similar to that induced by Ang II and also followed a similar time course (results not shown), again suggesting the implication of transcriptional activation. Indeed, in the presence of 100 nm PMA, HIF-1α mRNA levels are also strikingly increased (Fig. 4B). Given the common pathways activated by Ang II and PMA and the similarity between the effects of Ang II and PMA on HIF-1α, our results suggested that PKC activation was implicated in Ang II-mediated increases in HIF-1α. To confirm this, we treated cells with GF109203X, a compound shown to inhibit PKC activation by Ang II in VSMC (21Lassegue B. Alexander R.W. Nickenig G. Clark M. Murphy T.J. Griendling K.K. Mol. Pharmacol. 1995; 48: 601-609Google Scholar, 22Lassegue B. Sorescu D. Szocs K. Yin Q. Akers M. Zhang Y. Grant S.L. Lambeth J.D. Griendling K.K. Circ. Res. 2001; 88: 888-894Google Scholar). Preincubation of VSMC with GF109203X strongly inhibited HIF-1α protein levels following stimulation with Ang II and PMA (Fig. 4A). It is important to note that hypoxic induction of HIF-1α protein levels was not modified following incubation with GF109203X (Fig. 4A). In addition, GF109203X did not block normal receptor signaling, because p42/p44 MAPK activation by Ang II was not decreased. It has been shown that DAG-sensitive forms of PKC are only minimally responsible for p42/p44 MAPK activation by Ang II (23Liao D.F. Monia B. Dean N. Berk B.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 6146-6150Google Scholar). However, PKC activation was indeed inhibited by GF109203X, because the activation of p42/p44 MAPK by PMA was completely blocked in the presence of GF109203X. Taken together, these results suggest that PKC activity is implicated in the non-hypoxic up-regulation of HIF-1α by Ang II. More importantly, GF109203X inhibited Ang II- and PMA-induced HIF-1α and VEGF mRNA levels (Fig. 4B). GF109203X had no effect on HIF-1α mRNA levels in unstimulated cells (results not shown). These results indicate that activation of PKC is involved in the induction of HIF-1 by increasing HIF-1α mRNA levels. We have shown that ROS are implicated in the increase in HIF-1α protein levels following Ang II stimulation (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar). We therefore wanted to evaluate whether ROS activity was implicated in the Ang II-stimulated increase of HIF-1α mRNA. Cells were pretreated with inhibitors of Ang II-stimulated ROS production in VSMC, diphenyleneiodonium (DPI) and catalase. We have previously shown that these two agents can potently inhibit HIF-1α protein induction by Ang II (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar). When cells were pretreated with DPI or catalase prior to stimulation with Ang II, no inhibition of HIF-1α mRNA expression could be observed (Fig. 5A). As a control, Fig. 5B demonstrates that these compounds effectively inhibited HIF-1α protein expression. These results demonstrate that ROS are not implicated in increasing HIF-1α mRNA and suggest that Ang II activates a secondary ROS-dependent mechanism that is responsible for controlling HIF-1α protein induction. Recent studies brought us to consider that ROS activity could be implicated in HIF-1α protein translation. These studies have shown the following. 1) Ang II activates the PI3K/AKT pathway in a ROS-dependent manner in VSMC (24Ushio-Fukai M. Alexander R.W. Akers M. Yin Q. Fujio Y. Walsh K. Griendling K.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22699-22704Google Scholar); and 2) the PI3K pathway is implicated in heregulin receptor-mediated increases in HIF-1α protein translation in breast cancer cells (20Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Google Scholar). We therefore set out to investigate the possibility that, through the activation of ROS production and hence the PI3K pathway, Ang II could increase HIF-1α protein translation in VSMC. Our previous study (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar) demonstrated that the PI3K inhibitor Ly294002 could partially inhibit HIF-1α protein levels in VSMC stimulated by Ang II. When this experiment was repeated in new cell lines with different batches of Ly294002, we noted that this inhibition could be considerably stronger (Fig. 6A). Additionally, wortmannin, another PI3K inhibitor, and rapamycin, an inhibitor of a downstream target of the PI3K pathway, mTOR/FRAP, also impaired the induction of HIF-1α protein expression levels in response to Ang II. These results point to the implication of the PI3K pathway in HIF-1α induction by Ang II in VSMC. As a control, all these compounds effectively inhibited the phosphorylation of a downstream target of this pathway, p70S6 kinase (p70S6K) (Fig. 6A). However, these compounds had no effect on the Ang II-mediated increases in HIF-1α mRNA, indicating that PI3K is not implicated in the transcriptional regulation of HIF-1α (Fig. 6B). In agreement with previous studies by Ushio-Fukai et al. (24Ushio-Fukai M. Alexander R.W. Akers M. Yin Q. Fujio Y. Walsh K. Griendling K.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22699-22704Google Scholar), Fig. 5B shows that ROS inhibitors DPI and catalase also inhibited PI3K pathway activation (phosphorylation of p70S6K) by Ang II in VSMC. To demonstrate that Ang II increases HIF-1α protein synthesis, VSMC were or were not stimulated for 3 h followed by a pulse-labeling period with [35S]methionine/cysteine for 30 min. Very little labeled HIF-1α was immunoprecipitated from VSMC under control conditions (Fig. 7). Only minor changes in labeled HIF-1α could be seen in hypoxic conditions. These results indicate that, in VSMC, hypoxia relies on protein stabilization rather than increases in translation. This has been seen in other cell models, and it is possible that during the 30 min labeling following 3 h of hypoxia, the rate of new protein turnover was not elevated enough to be detected by this technique (20Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Google Scholar). However, a strong labeling of HIF-1α protein could be seen in cells treated with Ang II. This indicates that, in opposition to hypoxic induction, Ang II utilizes continued novel protein synthesis to maintain elevated levels of HIF-1α in VSMC. When cells were treated with rapamycin 10 min before the pulse-labeling period, HIF-1α labeling was blocked (Fig. 7). This implicates mTOR and the PI3K pathway in increasing HIF-1α protein synthesis. Laughner et al. (20Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Google Scholar) have shown that the 5′-UTR of HIF-1α mRNA is involved in the heregulin-mediated induction of HIF-1α protein synthesis. We therefore wanted to investigate whether the 5′-UTR of HIF-1α mRNA could be implicated in increasing HIF-1α translation in VSMC following Ang II stimulation. For this experiment, we used a luciferase reporter construct under the control of theHIF-1A gene promoter that included the 5′-UTR pHIF-1A-572/+284Luc (20Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Google Scholar). As was the case for the activation of the HIF-1α promoter construct (Fig. 3), this reporter was not activated by hypoxia (Fig. 8A). However, when cells were stimulated with Ang II, a strong activation of pHIF-1A-572/+284Luc could be observed. This increase was superior (by nearly 4-fold) to assays performed with the HIF-1α promoter only (compare Figs. 3 and 8A). To ensure that the 5′-UTR was not increasing transcription of the reporter, we performed a reverse transcription PCR analysis of firefly and Renilla luciferase mRNA. As seen in Fig. 8B, when cells transfected with the pHIF-1A-572/+284Luc or pHIF-1A-572/+32Luc were stimulated with Ang II, expression of firefly luciferase mRNA for both constructs was significantly increased to similar levels as compared with the controlRenilla luciferase mRNA. These results demonstrate that the HIF-1α 5′-UTR does not affect the transcription of the luciferase reporter. Taken together, these results indicate that the 5′-UTR of HIF-1α mRNA controls the increase of HIF-1α translation following Ang II stimulation. To investigate the implication of the ROS-activated PI3K pathway on this increase in HIF-1α translation, we evaluated the effect of a p22phox antisense plasmid and a dominant negative form of PI3K, p85ΔPI3K. p22phox is a critical component of the VSMC NADH/NADPH oxidase and is essential for Ang II-mediated ROS production in VSMC (24Ushio-Fukai M. Alexander R.W. Akers M. Yin Q. Fujio Y. Walsh K. Griendling K.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22699-22704Google Scholar). p85ΔPI3K is a mutant form of the PI3K subunit p85, which cannot interact with the P110 subunit and acts as a dominant negative (25Hara K. Yonezawa K. Sakaue H. Ando A. Kotani K. Kitamura T. Kitamura Y. Ueda H. Stephens L. Jackson T.R. Waterfield M.D. Kasuga M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 7415-7419Google Scholar). When VSMC were transfected with either p85ΔPI3K or antisense p22phox, a significant decrease was seen in the activation of the pHIF-1A-572/+284Luc reporter (Fig. 9, −572/+284). The constructs also decreased the activation of the HIF-1-targeted reporter construct PRE-tk-LUC (Fig. 9, HRE). However, p85ΔPI3K and antisense p22phox had no significant effect on theHIF-1A gene promoter construct pHIF-1A-572/+32Luc, which contains no 5′-UTR (Fig. 9, −572/+32). These results indicate that, in addition to increases in HIF-1α transcription, HIF-1 activation by Ang II is mediated through the ROS-activated PI3K pathway, which increases HIF-1α translation. Ubiquitously, hypoxia strongly increases HIF-1α protein expression levels by blocking the ubiquitin/proteasome-mediated degradation of HIF-1α through the inhibition of prolyl hydroxylation (8Maxwell P.H. Wiesener M.S. Chang G.W. Clifford S.C. Vaux E.C. Cockman M.E. Wykoff C.C. Pugh C.W. Maher E.R. Ratcliffe P.J. Nature. 1999; 399: 271-275Google Scholar, 9Jaakkola P. Mole D.R. Tian Y.M. Wilson M.I. Gielbert J. Gaskell S.J. Kriegsheim A. Hebestreit H.F. Mukherji M. Schofield C.J. Maxwell P.H. Pugh C.W. Ratcliffe P.J. Science. 2001; 292: 468-472Google Scholar, 10Ivan M. Kondo K. Yang H. Kim W. Valiando J. Ohh M. Salic A. Asara J.M. Lane W.S. Kaelin Jr., W.G. Science. 2001; 292: 464-468Google Scholar, 11Cockman M.E. Masson N. Mole D.R. Jaakkola P. Chang G.W. Clifford S.C. Maher E.R. Pugh C.W. Ratcliffe P.J. Maxwell P.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25733-25741Google Scholar, 12Bruick R.K. McKnight S.L. Science. 2001; 294: 1337-1340Google Scholar, 13Epstein A.C. Gleadle J.M. McNeill L.A. Hewitson K.S. O'Rourke J. Mole D.R. Mukherji M. Metzen E. Wilson M.I. Dhanda A. Tian Y.M. Masson N. Hamilton D.L. Jaakkola P. Barstead R. Hodgkin J. Maxwell P.H. Pugh C.W. Schofield C.J. Ratcliffe P.J. Cell. 2001; 107: 43-54Google Scholar). In VSMC, we have previously shown that Ang II can potently increase and activate the HIF-1 transcription complex (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar) to levels that can even surpass those achieved by hypoxic activation. In this study, we set out to identify the mechanisms that control this increase. We have found that, in contrast to hypoxia, Ang II modulates two different pathways to increase HIF-1α protein expression levels. The first involves an increase in the rate of HIF-1α mRNA transcription through a mechanism requiring the activation of the DAG-sensitive PKC. The second involves increasing the rate of translation of this newly produced HIF-1α mRNA by activating ROS production and the subsequent activation of the PI3K pathway. Together, these two pathways boost VSMC HIF-1α protein expression to levels that surpass hypoxic induction and lead to the activation of HIF-1-responsive genes such as VEGF. In VSMC, Ang II activates a large number of signaling pathways that are responsible for the modulation of vasomotor tone, cell growth, migration, and apoptosis (26Touyz R.M. Schiffrin E.L. Pharmacol. Rev. 2000; 52: 639-672Google Scholar). In this study, our task was to identify the signaling pathways that were responsible for increasing the expression levels of the HIF-1 complex. One signaling mechanism of interest was the protein kinase C pathway. In these cells, Ang II is a major activator of various forms of PKC that have been shown to activate a number of pathways and genes. PMA is an agonist that directly and potently activates DAG-sensitive isoforms of PKC. Our results show that PMA is one of the strongest activators of HIF-1α activity in VSMC. 2D. E. Richard, unpublished observations. We noticed that the time course of HIF-1α induction and activation by PMA closely resembles that of Ang II. We show that the common mediator involved in the increase of HIF-1α mRNA expression by Ang II and PMA is indeed PKC. The use of specific inhibitors of DAG-sensitive PKCs also potently blocks the induction of HIF-1α protein levels. Previous studies have also shown that PKC activity is required for Ang II-induced expression of nox1, a main component of the VSMC ROS-producing NADPH oxidase (22Lassegue B. Sorescu D. Szocs K. Yin Q. Akers M. Zhang Y. Grant S.L. Lambeth J.D. Griendling K.K. Circ. Res. 2001; 88: 888-894Google Scholar). The expression of nox1 or other elements during Ang II stimulation would also be blocked by actinomycin D, thereby explaining the strong potency of this drug on HIF-1α protein expression. Taken together, these results define a central role for PKC in Ang II-induced HIF-1 activation. PKC may control HIF at two levels: 1) by increasing HIF-1α mRNA levels; and 2) by increasing cellular ROS levels, which are essential in increasing the rate of HIF-1α protein translation. The HIF-1α gene promoter has been cloned from the human and mouse genome and shows an 80% conservation of the nucleotide sequence (17Wenger R.H. Rolfs A. Marti H.H. Guenet J.L. Gassmann M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 223: 54-59Google Scholar,27Iyer N.V. Leung S.W. Semenza G.L. Genomics. 1998; 52: 159-165Google Scholar). Although the promoter of rat HIF-1α gene has not yet been sequenced, we suspect that the sequence is similar to those of the mouse and human genes given the strong homology of the HIF-1α gene product. At this time, we have not identified the sequences that are responsible for the activation of the HIF-1α gene promoter by Ang II. Interestingly, a number of Sp1 sites exist in the HIF-1 promoter that are conserved between the mouse and the human sequence (27Iyer N.V. Leung S.W. Semenza G.L. Genomics. 1998; 52: 159-165Google Scholar). Studies have shown that PKC can increase the rate of gene transcription via the Sp1 transcription factor (28Han J.W. Ahn S.H. Kim Y.K. Bae G.U. Yoon J.W. Hong S. Lee H.Y. Lee Y.W. Lee H.W. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 42084-42090Google Scholar, 29Zheng X.L. Matsubara S. Diao C. Hollenberg M.D. Wong N.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 31747-31754Google Scholar). We are currently undertaking studies to investigate this possibility. Free radicals have been shown to play a crucial role in the activity of a number of signaling pathways in VSMC (24Ushio-Fukai M. Alexander R.W. Akers M. Yin Q. Fujio Y. Walsh K. Griendling K.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22699-22704Google Scholar, 30Griendling K.K. Sorescu D. Ushio-Fukai M. Circ. Res. 2000; 86: 494-501Google Scholar, 31Ushio-Fukai M. Alexander R.W. Akers M. Griendling K.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15022-15029Google Scholar, 32Brasier A.R. Jamaluddin M. Han Y. Patterson C. Runge M.S. Mol. Cell. Biochem. 2000; 212: 155-169Google Scholar, 33Rao G.N. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 16993-16999Google Scholar). We and others have shown that ROS production is important for the induction of HIF-1α protein levels by vasoactive hormones (14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar, 34Gorlach A. Diebold I. Schini-Kerth V.B. Berchner-Pfannschmidt U. Roth U. Brandes R.P. Kietzmann T. Busse R. Circ. Res. 2001; 89: 47-54Google Scholar). However, ROS inhibitors do not affect the ability of Ang II to up-regulate the rate of HIF-1α gene transcription, indicating that a second pathway was involved in the induction of HIF-1α by Ang II. Ushio-Fukai et al. (24Ushio-Fukai M. Alexander R.W. Akers M. Yin Q. Fujio Y. Walsh K. Griendling K.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22699-22704Google Scholar) has clearly shown that Ang II activates the PI3K pathway in VSMC. Recently, a number of studies have shown that this pathway plays an important role in the induction of HIF-1α by non-hypoxic factors such as heregulin and insulin (20Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Google Scholar, 35Treins C. Giorgetti-Peraldi S. Murdaca J. Semenza G.L. Van Obberghen E. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27975-27981Google Scholar). These factors have no effect on HIF-1α mRNA transcription but instead increase HIF-1α protein translation. We therefore wanted to investigate whether ROS-dependent activation of the PI3K pathway by Ang II in VSMC could increase HIF-1α translation of the newly increased HIF-1α mRNA. We demonstrate that this is indeed the case and that the 5′-UTR is critically involved in this increase. A possible mechanism by which Ang II could increase the rate of HIF-1α translation involves the activation of eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4F (eIF-4F) and/or the ribosomal S6 protein by the PI3K/p70S6K/mTOR pathway. p70S6K regulates the translation of a group of mRNAs possessing a 5′-terminal oligopyrimidine tract (5′TOP), a stretch of 4–14 pyrimidines found at the extreme 5′-terminus of certain mRNAs (36Dufner A. Thomas G. Exp. Cell Res. 1999; 253: 100-109Google Scholar). The HIF-1α 5′-UTR contains these tracts, including a long conserved sequence in the extreme 5′ terminus (27Iyer N.V. Leung S.W. Semenza G.L. Genomics. 1998; 52: 159-165Google Scholar). Phosphorylation of the S6 protein of the 40 S ribosomal unit by p70S6K increases the translation of the 5′-TOP mRNAs. In VSMC, the p70S6K pathway has been shown to be implicated in the increases in protein translation induced by Ang II (37Giasson E. Meloche S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5225-5231Google Scholar). The eIF-4F complex is formed by interactions between eIF-4E, eIF-4G, and other factors. This complex binds to the 5′-mRNA cap structure and permits the recruitment of the eukaryotic ribosome (38Raught B. Gingras A.C. Sonenberg N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 7037-7044Google Scholar). eIF-4E activity is blocked by interaction with 4E-binding proteins (4E-BPs). This interaction is regulated by phosphorylation. Hypo-phosphorylated 4E-BPs strongly bind eIF-4E, whereas hyper-phosphorylated 4E-BPs release eIF-4E. The phosphorylation of 4E-BP is regulated by PI3K/mTOR. In VSMC, Ang II increases 4E-BP1 phosphorylation (39Fleurent M. Gingras A.C. Sonenberg N. Meloche S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 4006-4012Google Scholar) through the PI3K pathway. 3G.A. Robitaille and D.E. Richard, unpublished results. eIF-4E is also phosphorylated in VSMC following Ang II stimulation, leading to increased protein synthesis (40Rao G.N. Griendling K.K. Frederickson R.M. Sonenberg N. Alexander R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7180-7184Google Scholar). PKC activity was shown to be implicated in this phosphorylation, suggesting again that PKC plays a central role in the induction of HIF-1α by Ang II. A second study has also shown that ROS are implicated in eIF-4E phosphorylation, further supporting our findings (33Rao G.N. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 16993-16999Google Scholar). During our previous study, two observations indicated that, in VSMC, hypoxia and Ang II acted through different pathways. First, the hypoxic and Ang II effects were additive, and, second, DPI completely blocked Ang II-mediated HIF-1α protein increases while having no effect on the HIF-1α induction by hypoxia. In this study we clearly demonstrate that the actions of Ang II in VSMC are distinct from those of hypoxia. It is essential to understand that, in VSMC, hypoxia had no effect on the rate of HIF-1α transcription or translation. We believe that, in this way, Ang II can increase the low basal expression levels of HIF-1α mRNA in quiescent VSMC and effectively translate the messenger, leading to high HIF-1α protein expression levels during Ang II stimulation, whereas hypoxia relies on increased protein stability to maintain elevated HIF-1α protein expression levels. 4E.L. Pagé and D.E. Richard, unpublished results. Given the low expression levels of HIF-1α mRNA in quiescent VSMC, this would explain the mediocre induction of HIF-1α in response to hypoxia. However, when cells are stimulated with both hypoxia and hormones or growth factors, the induction of HIF-1α is additive because of the different pathways activated (see Ref. 14Richard D.E. Berra E. Pouyssegur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Google Scholar). In conclusion, our study provides data that identifies two interesting mechanisms by which Ang II (and other hormones like thrombin) activates the HIF-1 complex. By binding to the AT1 receptor, Ang II activates at least two distinct pathways involved in the up-regulation of HIF-1. The first, by increasing HIF-1α mRNA expression levels, leads to increased HIF-1α protein expression activity. The second, which involves ROS production, results in an increased rate of translation of the HIF-1α protein. An active HIF-1 complex is thus formed that increases the expression of its target genes, including VEGF. Given the importance of these genes in cellular physiology, we strongly believe that these studies will have a strong impact on vascular biology. We are grateful to Drs. Jean-Claude Chambard, Kathy Griendling, Masato Kasuga, Steven McKnight, and Gregg Semenza for providing plasmids, Drs. Richard Larivière and Marcel Lebel for support and reagents, Dominique Grall and Guylaine Soucy for technical assistance, and Drs. Edurne Berra, Fergus R. McKenzie, and Francesc Viñals for editorial work and many helpful suggestions.

Insecticidal crystal proteins of Bacillus thuringiensis bind to receptors in the midgut of susceptible insects leading to pore formation and death of the insect. The identity of the receptor is not clearly established. Recently a direct interaction between a cloned and heterologously expressed aminopeptidase (slapn) from Spodoptera lituraand the Cry1C protein was demonstrated by immunofluorescence andin vitro ligand blot interaction. Here we show that administration of slapn double-stranded RNA to S. litura larvae reduces its expression. As a consequence of the reduced expression, a corresponding decrease in the sensitivity of these larvae to Cry1C toxin was observed. The gene silencing was retained during the insect's moulting and development and transmitted to the subsequent generation albeit with a reduced effect. These results directly implicate larval midgut aminopeptidase N as receptor for Bacillus thuringiensis insecticidal proteins.
