G6PDH (1 μm) and MDH were treated at 52 °C together (triangles) or separately and mixed after heat treatment (circles). The fraction (%) of precipited G6PDH (15,800 × g, 20 min) (▴, ●) compared with the rates of chaperone-mediated G6PDH reactivation (▵, ○).B, dose-dependent effect of pre-aggregated G6PDH on the precipitation and chaperone recoverability of MDH aggregates. MDH (1 μm) and pre-aggregated G6PDH (pre-treated for 15 min at 52 °C) were treated for one hour at 43 °C together (triangles) or separately and mixed after the 43 °C treatment (circles). The fraction (%) of precipitated MDH (▴, ●) compared with the rates of chaperone-mediated MDH reactivation (▵, ○). MDH (1 μm) and BSA were treated at 56 °C together (triangles) or separately and mixed after the heat treatment (circles). The fraction (%) of precipitated MDH (▴, ●) compared with the rates of chaperone-mediated MDH reactivation (▵, ○).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) A reciprocal mild solubilization effect of the MDH aggregate by co-aggregating G6PDH was observed. Whereas only 100 ×g sufficed to precipitate half the MDH aggregates alone, 4,000 × g were necessary to precipitate the same amount of co-aggregated MDH in the presence of a 5-fold excess of more soluble G6PDH aggregates (Fig. 2 C). This apparent solubilization effect independently demonstrates that stable MDH-G6PDH hetero-oligomers did form during co-aggregation. Remarkably, alongside with acceleration of aggregation kinetics, chaperone-mediated disaggregation was also impaired in hetero-aggregates. Hence, when MDH and G6PDH in equimolar amounts were co-aggregated, the rates of chaperone-mediated reactivation was eight times slower for MDH-G6PDH hetero-aggregates than for G6PDH homo-aggregates formed at the same temperature (Fig. 3 A). In contrast, when in a control experiment, preformed MDH and G6PDH homo-aggregates were mixed after heat treatment, the original solubility and chaperone-recoverability of either protein remained unaffected (Fig. 3 A). Hence, compared with homologous aggregation, heterologous aggregation affects both solubility and chaperone recoverability. To determine the nature of the interactions between two proteins, leading to decreased solubility and chaperone recoverability, a dose-response of G6PDH precipitation and chaperone recoverability was performed in the presence of increasing concentrations of MDH. Unexpected from one-to-one hetero-aggregates, sub-stoichiometric amounts of MDH fully sufficed to carry both effects. As little as one 30-kDa MDH molecule sufficed to accelerate the precipitation and inhibit chaperone recovery of 4–5 60-kDa G6PDH molecules (Figs. 2 C and 3 A). In a reciprocal experiment, the presence of sub-stoichiometric amounts of G6PDH seeds (pre-aggregated at 52 °C) affected the MDH solubility and chaperone recoverability during and following a mild denaturation at 43 °C (Fig. 3 B). Induced MDH precipitation was confirmed using pre-aggregated seeds from a totally different protein, BSA, which is widely used as a stabilizing agent for labile proteins in vitro. Whereas at 56 °C, native BSA expectedly reduced the rate of MDH inactivation and aggregation (not shown), the presence of BSA in the aggregation rendered MDH aggregates significantly more resistant to disaggregating chaperones after the stress (Fig. 3 C). It is concluded that the ability of aggregates from one protein to influence, and even propagate, aggregation of another protein is a general property shared by many proteins, unrelated to amyloidogenic and prion proteins. Most chaperones can bind partially unfolded intermediates or small aggregates and thus prevent the formation of larger aggregates during stress. Hence, the role of binding chaperones on seed-induced MDH aggregation was addressed. The presence of DnaK (in binding-only mode without ATP) or the small heat shock protein IbpB efficiently inhibited seed-induced precipitation of MDH during mild denaturation at 43 °C (Fig.4 A). As previously shown in Fig. 3 B, the MDH solubility with a 0.5 μmG6PDH seed, but without chaperones, was ∼30% (∼70% precipitation). Yet, the non-catalytic binding effect of equimolar DnaK, or of IbpB chaperones on MDH solubility in the presence a G6PDH seed, was increased to 60 and 47%, respectively (Fig. 4 A). A mild increase was also observed in the solubility of the G6PDH seed (not shown). It can be concluded that potential cascade interprecipitation events among different proteins may be prevented by binding chaperones capable of sequestering seeds and aggregation substrates. During a prolonged stress, the binding capacity of the chaperone network may be overwhelmed (20Lorimer G.H. FASEB J. 1996; 10: 5-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (198) Google Scholar). The effect of active disaggregation by ClpB and KJE was therefore tested on the outcome of seed-induced aggregation. G6PDH treated at 52 °C in the presence of MDH seeds (as in Fig. 3 A), was refolded after the stress by limiting amounts of chaperones at a slower rate than G6PDH treated alone at the same temperature but at a faster rate than G6PDH treated alone at a higher temperature, 62 °C (Fig. 4 B). As expected from the higher oligomeric state of seeded aggregates (Fig.2 C), a ClpB dose-response on refolding rates revealed that ClpB has a lower apparent affinity (EC50 0.15) for seeded G6PDH, than for G6PDH alone (EC50 0.09) (at 52 °C). The recovery of G6PDH prepared at 62 °C depended even more on ClpB (EC50 0.22), indicating that cross-seeding can mimic the damaging effects of higher temperatures and generally increase the requirement by aggregating proteins for molecular chaperones. Depending on cellular and environmental conditions, active flexible proteins may populate a number of very similar native structures (21Luque I. Leavitt S.A. Freire E. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 2002; 31: 235-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Aggregated proteins are often more rigid, less soluble, and tend to assemble into a wide continuum of dissimilar high oligomeric structures. Hence, non-pathogenic proteins that normally form amorphous aggregates can be induced to form highly structured amyloid-like fibrils (reviewed in Ref. 22Dobson C.M. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1999; 24: 329-332Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1702) Google Scholar), suggesting that unfolding conditions dictate individual polypeptides to adopt distinct, highly variable aggregated structures (3Khurana R. Gillespie J.R. Talapatra A. Minert L.J. Ionescu-Zanetti C. Millett I. Fink A.L. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 3525-3535Crossref PubMed Scopus (292) Google Scholar, 4Diamant S. Ben-Zvi A.P. Bukau B. Goloubinoff P. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 21107-21113Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). Here, molecular chaperones and differential centrifugation were used to address the degree of structural variation in different populations of homo-aggregates from non-pathogenic proteins. Depending on the denaturing conditions, proteins reproducibly formed very different aggregates, from small soluble chaperone-sensitive amorphous aggregates to more compact insoluble, chaperone-resistant aggregates. This is reminiscent of the PrPC protein, which in mammals forms different strains of PrPSC, with distinct sensitivities to proteolytic enzymes, specific rates of infectivity, and different locations in the brain (23Collinge J. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 2001; 24: 519-550Crossref PubMed Scopus (1110) Google Scholar). Our results suggest that prions are not an exception. Some cohesive aggregates have been suggested to derive from specific domain-swapping interactions (24Liu Y. Gotte G. Libonati M. Eisenberg D. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2001; 8: 211-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (267) Google Scholar, 25Rousseau F. Schymkowitz J.W. Wilkinson H.R. Itzhaki L.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 5596-5601Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar), implying that aggregation can take place only among identical or very similar polypeptides. Dissimilar co-aggregating polypeptides should therefore not interact with each other or inhibit, rather than accelerate, each other's aggregations (26Uversky V.N. Li J. Souillac P. Millett I.S. Doniach S. Jakes R. Goedert M. Fink A.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 11970-11978Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar). Indeed, P22 tail spikes and coat proteins do not form hetero-aggregates (27Betts S. King J. Structure Fold. Des. 1999; 7: R131-R139Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (65) Google Scholar). However, here we show that cross-interactions between dissimilar co-aggregating proteins do take place and that they interfere with each other's kinetics of aggregation and chaperone-recoverability. This is confirmed in vivo, whereby heterologous aggregation between huntingtin and p53 has been observed in mammalian cells (28Steffan J.S. Kazantsev A. Spasic-Boskovic O. Greenwald M. Zhu Y.Z. Gohler H. Wanker E.E. Bates G.P. Housman D.E. Thompson L.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 6763-6768Crossref PubMed Scopus (878) Google Scholar). In Caenorhabditis elegans, expression of a spontaneously aggregating protein containing 82 poly-glutamine repeats (Q82), increased cytotoxicity, and sequestrated otherwise soluble proteins with shorter poly-glutamine repeats (Q19 and HRP1) (29Satyal S.H. Schmidt E. Kitagawa K. Sondheimer N. Lindquist S. Kramer J.M. Morimoto R.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 5750-5755Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar). Similarly, the spontaneous aggregation of the yeast prion [PIN(+)] induces the conversion of a number of soluble yeast proteins into different types of prions, suggesting a general mechanism of induced heterologous prion aggregation (30Derkatch I.L. Bradley M.E. Hong J.Y. Liebman S.W. Cell. 2001; 106: 171-182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (491) Google Scholar). One major implication of hetero-aggregation is that high cohesiveness in aggregates may not necessarily result from specific domain-swapping events but also from cooperative interactions between low-specificity sites, such as small hydrophobic patches and polar zippers on the surface of newly formed β-sheets (1Fink A.L. Folding Des. 1998; 3: R9-23Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1048) Google Scholar, 31Perutz M.F. Johnson T. Suzuki M. Finch J.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 5355-5358Crossref PubMed Scopus (951) Google Scholar). Moreover, the intra-molecular rearrangement observed in the secondary structures of prionogenic, amyloidogenic, and common heat-induced aggregates are inconsistent with the high degree of structural preservation required for precise domain swapping (1Fink A.L. Folding Des. 1998; 3: R9-23Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1048) Google Scholar). Sub-stoichiometric amounts of one fast co-aggregating protein can significantly increase aggregation kinetics, oligomeric states, and chaperone-resistance properties of an otherwise soluble, slow-aggregating protein. This suggests that a conformational change, initially induced by heterologous MDH-G6PDH interactions, is further propagated to other G6PDH aggregates, without necessarily involving direct contacts with the initial MDH seed. This proteinaceous infectious behavior is similar to that of yeast prions, whereby a minority of one type of prion affects the onset and propagation kinetics of other yeast prions (30Derkatch I.L. Bradley M.E. Hong J.Y. Liebman S.W. Cell. 2001; 106: 171-182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (491) Google Scholar). We show here that non-pathogenic proteins may also generate under stress proteinaceous infectious aggregates. Structurally fluid small aggregates formed by acid precipitation of non-pathogenic proteins are more toxic to mammalian cells than larger more stable amyloids (32Bucciantini M. Giannoni E. Chiti F. Baroni F. Formigli L. Zurdo J. Taddei N. Ramponi G. Dobson C.M. Stefani M. Nature. 2002; 416: 507-511Crossref PubMed Scopus (2154) Google Scholar). Likewise, prion seeding is more efficient when initiated with structurally fluid small oligomeric sup35 complexes, than with large “mature” particles (33Serio T.R. Cashikar A.G. Kowal A.S. Sawicki G.J. Moslehi J.J. Serpell L. Arnsdorf M.F. Lindquist S.L. Science. 2000; 289: 1317-1321Crossref PubMed Scopus (828) Google Scholar). Similarly, we found that small soluble G6PDH aggregates formed at 52 °C were more efficient seeds than insoluble large aggregates formed at 62 °C (not shown). Hence, proteinaceous infectious behavior in non-pathogenic proteins may reach an optimum during the early phases of stress-denaturation in a mechanism that does not fundamentally differ from the “nucleation polymerization” model suggested for prion propagation (33Serio T.R. Cashikar A.G. Kowal A.S. Sawicki G.J. Moslehi J.J. Serpell L. Arnsdorf M.F. Lindquist S.L. Science. 2000; 289: 1317-1321Crossref PubMed Scopus (828) Google Scholar, 34Borchsenius A.S. Wegrzyn R.D. Newnam G.P. Inge-Vechtomov S.G. Chernoff Y.O. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 6683-6691Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). In stressed cells, many sensitive proteins may alternate between native and partially unfolded states, which, depending on the conditions and the presence of seeds, may choose to aggregate or revert to the native state. We showed here that the stability of one protein may depend on the stability and aggregation-propensity of other unrelated proteins in the same cellular compartment, implying a new, unsuspected network of protein-protein interactions in the cell. Yet molecular chaperones can control such interactions by sequestering active seeds and aggregation-prone intermediates. Neutralization of catalytic-seeds is likely to be more powerful than direct prevention-of-aggregation of intermediates, the later depending on limited non-catalytic one-to-one interactions with the chaperones. During prolonged stresses, once unfolding intermediates exceed the binding capacity of cellular chaperones, aggregation may prevail and disaggregating chaperones become essential to remove toxic seeds and intermediates. The involvement of molecular chaperones in aggregate detoxification has been demonstrated in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Over-expression of Hsp100 and/or Hsp70 dissolves stress-induced aggregates in E. coli (11Mogk A. Tomoyasu T. Goloubinoff P. Rudiger S. Roder D. Langen H. Bukau B. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 6934-6949Crossref PubMed Scopus (516) Google Scholar, 35Tomoyasu T. Mogk A. Langen H. Goloubinoff P. Bukau B. Mol. Microbiol. 2001; 40: 397-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar, 36Sakahira H. Breuer P. Hayer-Hartl M.K. Hartl F.U. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; (in press)PubMed Google Scholar) as well as polyglutamine-rich aggregates in yeast and animals (reviewed in Ref, 36). Moreover, cascade aggregations are observed when the expression of Hsp networks is low, such as during apoptosis (37Garrido C. Gurbuxani S. Ravagnan L. Kroemer G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2001; 286: 433-442Crossref PubMed Scopus (665) Google Scholar) or aging (38Soti C. Csermely P. Biogerontology. 2000; 1: 225-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Our in vitro results demonstrate that as expected from seed-induced increase in aggregate size, the dependence on ClpB for efficient disaggregation increases. It is therefore important, especially for mammalian cells devoid of ClpB-like chaperones, to maintain aggregates small enough for effective scavenging by the Hsp70 chaperone system alone (12Ben-Zvi A.P. Goloubinoff P. J. Struct. Biol. 2001; 135: 84-93Crossref PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar), or alternatively push aggregation to completion (34Borchsenius A.S. Wegrzyn R.D. Newnam G.P. Inge-Vechtomov S.G. Chernoff Y.O. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 6683-6691Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar) and form large compact and therefore less-toxic structures, such as inclusion bodies and aggresomes (39Kopito R.R. Trends Cell Biol. 2000; 10: 524-530Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1602) Google Scholar). Our results suggest that a network of molecular chaperones can play the role of an intracellular defense mechanism against protein pathogens. It can specifically recognize infectious particles, such as proteinaceous infectious seeds, and prevent their propagation among other proteins in the cell by passive sequestration or active disruption of the infectious agent. Moreover, we show that properties initially assigned to prions, such as multiple strains, infectivity, compactness, and resistance to chaperones, are also shared by regular proteins lacking polyglutamine motives, or associated pathologies. Yet mutant, amyloidogenic, and prion proteins may distinguish themselves from the other proteins in the cell by their ability to undergo conformational rearrangements at or around physiological conditions (40Leclerc E. Peretz D. Ball H. Sakurai H. Legname G. Serban A. Prusiner S.B. Burton D.R. Williamson R.A. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 1547-1554Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar) when HSPs are not abundant. It is moreover possible that mutant, poly-glutamine rich, amyloidogenic, and prionigenic proteins form more compact aggregates that naturally resist the chaperone and protease networks and consequently evolve detectable pathological aggregates during the lifetime of a given organism. Our results imply that environmental stresses may strongly influence the ability of cells to counteract the early onset pathologic protein aggregations.

Regulator of G protein signaling (RGS) proteins constitute a family of over 20 proteins that negatively regulate heterotrimeric G protein-coupled receptor signaling pathways by enhancing endogenous GTPase activities of G protein α subunits. RGSZ1, one of the RGS proteins specifically localized to the brain, has been cloned previously and described as a selective GTPase accelerating protein for Gαz subunit. Here, we employed several methods to provide new evidence that RGSZ1 interacts not only with Gαz, but also with Gαi, as supported byin vitro binding assays and functional studies. Using glutathione S-transferase fusion protein pull-down assays, glutathione S-transferase-RGSZ1 protein was shown to bind35S-labeled Gαi1 protein in anAlF AlF4− dependent manner. The interaction between RGSZ1 and Gαi was confirmed further by co-immunoprecipitation studies and yeast two-hybrid experiments using a quantitative luciferase reporter gene. Extending these observations to functional studies, RGSZ1 accelerated endogenous GTPase activity of Gαi1 in single-turnover GTPase assays. Human RGSZ1 functionally regulated GPA1 (a yeast Gαi-like protein)-mediated yeast pheromone response when expressed in a SST2 (yeast RGS protein) knockout strain. In PC12 cells, transfected RGSZ1 blocked mitogen-activated protein kinase activity induced by UK14304, an α2-adrenergic receptor agonist. Furthermore, RGSZ1 attenuated D2 dopamine receptor agonist-induced serum response element reporter gene activity in Chinese hamster ovary cells. In summary, these data suggest that RGSZ1 serves as a GTPase accelerating protein for Gαi and regulates Gαi-mediated signaling, thus expanding the potential role of RGSZ1 in G protein-mediated cellular activities. Extending these observations to functional studies, RGSZ1 accelerated endogenous GTPase activity of Gαi1 in single-turnover GTPase assays. Human RGSZ1 functionally regulated GPA1 (a yeast Gαi-like protein)-mediated yeast pheromone response when expressed in a SST2 (yeast RGS protein) knockout strain. In PC12 cells, transfected RGSZ1 blocked mitogen-activated protein kinase activity induced by UK14304, an α2-adrenergic receptor agonist. Furthermore, RGSZ1 attenuated D2 dopamine receptor agonist-induced serum response element reporter gene activity in Chinese hamster ovary cells. RGS2 shows more potent inhibition of Gαq-coupled signaling than Gαi signaling in vivo andin vitro (32Heximer S.P. Srinivasa S.P. Bernstein L.S. Bernard J.L. Linder M.E. Hepler J.R. Blumer K.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 34253-34259Google Scholar). RGSZ1 was independently identified by two groups as a specific GAP protein of Gαz. Wang et al. (33Wang J. Ducret A. Tu Y. Kozasa T. Aebersold R. Ross E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26014-26025Google Scholar, 46Wang J. Tu Y. Woodson J. Song X. Ross E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 5732-5740Google Scholar) directly purified the RGSZ1 protein from bovine brain tissue lysate by its GAP activity toward Gαz, whereas Glick et al. (34Glick J.L. Meigs T.E. Miron A. Casey P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26008-26013Google Scholar) identified the RGSZ1 using Gαz Q205L mutant as “bait” in a yeast two-hybrid screen of a human brain library. The sequence of the hRGSZ1 protein is 83% identical to a bovine RET-RGS1 and 56% identical to hGAIP. RGSZ1 is exclusively expressed in brain, with the highest concentrations in the caudate nucleus and the temporal lobe, implying that RGSZ1 may play a role in regulating signals in these brain regions. RGSZ1 was reported to show high selectivity for Gαz in an in vitro GTPase assay, exhibiting at least 20–100-fold selectivity for Gαz over other Gαi family members and no GAP activities for Gαq and Gαs (33Wang J. Ducret A. Tu Y. Kozasa T. Aebersold R. Ross E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26014-26025Google Scholar). To date, however, RGSZ1 functional studies have largely relied on in vitro GTPase assays. The precise physiological function of RGSZ1, especially with regard to its role in cell signaling, is still not clear. To further understand the function of RGSZ1, we employed several methods to investigate the physical and functional interactions of RGSZ1 with other Gαi family members. We found that RGSZ1 protein bound to Gαi1 protein, as well as Gαz protein, in an AlF4−-dependent manner. Also, RGSZ1 accelerated the endogenous GTPase activity of Gαi1 in single-turnover GTPase assays. The interaction between RGSZ1 and Gαi was further confirmed by yeast two-hybrid experiments. Studies using intact cells showed that hRGSZ1 functionally regulated the yeast G protein (GPA1, Gαi-like)-mediated pheromone response. Furthermore, RGSZ1 attenuated D2 dopamine receptor agonist-induced serum response element (SRE) reporter gene activity in CHO cells and also blocked MAP kinase activity induced by a α2-adrenergic receptor agonist in PC12 cells. In summary, these data suggest that RGSZ1 may GAP Gαi and regulate Gαi-mediated cell signaling. cDNAs for hRGSZ1, hRGS4, and hGAIP were amplified from a human brain cDNA library (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) by PCR using oligonucleotides based on published sequences (21Druey K.M. Blumer K.J. Kang V.H. Kehrl J.H. Nature. 1996; 379: 742-746Google Scholar, 33Wang J. Ducret A. Tu Y. Kozasa T. Aebersold R. Ross E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26014-26025Google Scholar, 34Glick J.L. Meigs T.E. Miron A. Casey P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26008-26013Google Scholar, 35De Vries L. Mousli M. Wurmser A. Farquhar M.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11916-11920Google Scholar). The PCR products were cloned into the corresponding sites of pGEX-4T-1 (Amersham Biosciences), pQE-60 (Qiagen, Valencia, CA) and pcDNA3(+) vectors (Invitrogen). All constructs were confirmed by DNA sequencing. The GST-RGSZ1 and GST-RGS4 fusion proteins were purified from Escherichia coli using a B-PERTMGST fusion protein purification kit (Pierce). The RGSZ1-His6 protein was purified from E. coli via a nickel-nitrilotriacetic resin-based chromatography. The RGS4 core domain peptide (166 amino acids) and Gαi1-His6 protein were purified as described previously (36Moy F.J. Chanda P.K. Cockett M.I. Edris W. Jones P.G. Mason K. Semus S. Powers R. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 7063-7073Google Scholar). A RGS7 core domain (residues 330–448) was a gift from Dr. Philip Jones (Wyeth, Princeton, NJ). (Lake Placid, NY). The GTPase activity of Gαi1protein was measured by monitoring free γ-Pi release from bound GTP as described previously (25Berman D.M. Wilkie T.M. Gilman A.G. Cell. 1996; 86: 445-452Google Scholar). Briefly, 1 μmGαi1 protein was incubated with 1 μm[γ-32P]GTP in a buffer containing 10 mmHepes (pH 7.5), 5 mm EDTA, 2 μm GTP, 1 mm DTT, and 0.05% Lubrol, at 30 °C for 30 min. The [γ-32P]GTP-loaded Gαi1 was separated from unbound [γ-32P]GTP by passing through a gel filtration column (Princeton Separations), and diluted to 200 nm with ice-cold assay buffer (10 mm Hepes, 5 mm EDTA, 2 μm GTP, 1 mm DTT, and 0.05% Lubrol, pH 7.5). The Gαi1 GTPase was initiated by adding 10 mm MgCl2 and 100 μm GTP, with or without RGS protein. The reaction was stopped by adding 5% Norit activated charcoal in 50 mm NaPO4 (pH 3.0). Following a centrifugation, the supernatant containing free32Pi was counted. All assays were performed at 0 or 15 °C. All recombinant RGS and Gαi1 proteins used here were expressed and purified from E. coli (>90% purity). Approximately 65% of the Gαi1 protein bound to GTPγS in a standard binding assay. The observed rate constants (Kobs) for each were calculated using GraphPad Prism2 program based on a one-phase exponential association equationY = Ymax[1 − exp(−KX)]. The GST-RGSZ1 fusion protein was prepared using the pGEX-4T-1 vector and E. coli strain JM109. [35S]Gαi1 and [35S]Gαz were generated by an in vitro TnT T7-coupled transcription/translation system as description by the manufacturer (Promega, Madison, WI). 5 μg of GST-RGSZ1 was attached to glutathionine-agarose beads (50 μl of 50% beads) and incubated with 2 μl of 35S-labeled Gα subunits in 500 μl of binding buffer (50 mm Hepes, pH 8.0, 1 mm EDTA, 100 μm GDP, 1 mmDTT, 10 mm MgSO4, 0.05% Lubrol, and 0.05% bovine serum albumin) for 4 h at 4 °C with gentle shaking. The beads were washed three times with the binding buffer and then re-suspended in the SDS-PAGE sample buffer. Labeled proteins were resolved with SDS-PAGE and visualized by autoradiography. CHO-K1 cells maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum were seeded in 100-mm diameter dishes (3 × 106 cells/well) the day before transfection. Cells were transfected with RGSZ1 and Gαi1 plasmids or with empty pcDNA3 (+) vector using LipofectAMINE PLUSTM(Invitrogen). All subsequent procedures were carried out at 4 °C. Cells were harvested 40–48 h thereafter in 1 ml of lysis buffer (20 mm HEPES, pH 7.5, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaCl, 10 μg/ml aprotinin, 5 μg/ml leupeptin, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) with 2% Triton X-100, and then incubated for 1 h with gentle shaking. The unsolubilized fractions were removed by centrifugation at 100,000 × g for 1 h. The supernatant was diluted with the lysis buffer without detergent to reach a final concentration of 1% Triton X-100. The supernatant was pre-cleared with nonimmune rabbit serum and protein A-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences). Then a polyclonal antibody against RGSZ1 (1 μg/ml, final) and 50 μl of 50% protein A-Sepharose beads were added to the supernatant and incubated overnight at 4 °C with gentle shaking. Immunoprecipitates were collected by centrifugation, washed three times with lysis buffer containing 1% Triton X-100, and resuspended in sample buffer for SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE). Following electrophoresis, proteins were transferred to the nitrocellulose membrane and probed with a monoclonal antibody against Gαi1 (Upstate Biotechnology, Inc.) using standard Western blotting procedure with ECL chemiluminescence (AmershamBiosciences). Human RGSZ1 was subcloned into theNcoI/BamHI sites of pACT2 vector (Clontech) to generate a Gal4 DNA activation domain (AD) fusion protein. Human Gαi1, Gαi1Q204L mutant, Gαi2, and Gαi3 were subcloned individually into EcoRI and PstI sites of pGBKT7 vector (Clontech) to generate GAL4 DNA-binding domain (BD)fusion proteins. A Gal-luciferase reporter (Kp126) was generated by cloning the firefly luciferase gene into theBamHI and SalI sites of pEK1 vector (66Ozenberger B.A. Young K.H. Mol. Endocrinol. 1995; 9 (32): 1321-1329Google Scholar). All constructs were confirmed by DNA sequencing. Yeast strains were generated by co-transformation of plasmids into CY770 (66Ozenberger B.A. Young K.H. Mol. Endocrinol. 1995; 9 (32): 1321-1329Google Scholar) using the lithium acetate method and growth on selective medium. For each strain, 30 colonies were mixed in liquid medium (−Trp−Leu−Ura) and grown overnight at 30 °C with continuous shaking. Yeast cells were diluted to an A600 of 0.15 and then grown for 3 h at 30 °C. The luciferase reporter gene activity was determined using a LucLiteTM kit (Packard, Meriden, CT) and a luminescence counter (Packard) in a single photon counting mode. The cDNAs of hRGSZ1, hRGS2, and SST2 were cloned into theBamHI/ClaI sites of p426TEF vector (ATCC, Manassas, VA). The yeast SST2 knock-out strain (KY113) was transformed with the plasmid encoding RGS2, RGSZ1, or SST2, and grown in selective media. Transformants were selected, cultured using standard conditions, diluted to 0.5 of A600 in 5 ml to produce a lawn of cells. Plates were dried for 2 h at 30 °C, and then α factor was spotted on the surface of the agar plate in a series of dilutions (1, 10, 100, and 1000 μm), and incubated at 30 °C for 2–3 days. PC12 cell lines stably expressing eGFP or eGFP-RGSZ1 were selected and cultured in DMEM containing 10% horse serum, 5% fetal bovine serum, and 50 μg/ml G418. The p44/42 MAPK activity was measured using a MAP kinase assay kit from Cell Signaling Technology (Beverly, MA). Briefly, cells were starved overnight in serum-free medium and then treated with UK14304 (Sigma) for 5 min. Thereafter cells were immediately transferred on ice and washed once with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline. Cells were harvested using a cell lysis buffer from the kit plus 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. MAPK activity was determined according to the manufacturer's instruction. CHO-K1 cells stably expressing D2 dopamine receptor (D2R) were maintained in six-well plates in DMEM containing 10% fetal bovine serum, 5 μg/ml mycophenolic acid, 0.25 mg/ml xanthine, and HT supplement. Cells were transfected with cis-reporter plasmid pSRE-luc (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA), which contains a SRE-dependent luciferase gene, lacZgene, and RGSZ1 plasmids. Cells were then starved in serum-free medium overnight and treated for 5 h with 10 μm quinpirole, an agonist of D2R. Cell lysates were prepared, and luciferase and β-galactosidase activities were measured using the dual reporter gene assay kit from Tropix (Bedford, MA). Measurements were performed with a luminometer, and luciferase activities were normalized to β-galactosidase activities. RGS proteins bind to a specific conformational state of Gα subunits. RGS4 binds only to the transition state ( O2.¯-bound) of Gαi1 subunits (13Berman D.M. Kozasa T. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27209-27212Google Scholar), whereas RGS2 binds to both transition state and active (GTPγS-bound) form of Gαq (37Heximer S.P. Watson N. Linder M.E. Blumer K.J. Hepler J.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 14389-14393Google Scholar). Both RGS4 and RGS2, however, do not bind to the GDP-bound form of Gα subunits. To determine the physical interaction between RGSZ1 and Gαi, a GST-RGSZ1 fusion protein was attached to glutathione-agarose beads and incubated individually with anin vitro translated, [35S]methionine-labeled Gαi1 wild type, GαiQ204L, GαiR178C or Gαz wild type, GαzQ205L, GαzR179C, with and without GTPγS or AlF4−. As shown in Fig. 1, RGSZ1 bound to Gαi1(lane 10) and Gαz (lane 4) only in the presence of AlF4−, but not in the presence of GTPγS (lanes 3 and 9). RGSZ1 did not bind to the constitutively active QL (lanes 5 and11) and RC mutants (lanes 6 and12) of Gαz or Gαi1. This observation indicates that RGSZ1 directly binds to both Gαi1 and Gαz in their transition states. To further investigate the physical interaction between RGSZ1 and Gαi1 in cells, co-immunoprecipitation of RGSZ1 and Gαi1 in CHO-K1 cells was also determined (Fig. 2). Cells were co-transfected with Gαi1 and RGSZ1, and cell extracts were prepared 2 days after transfection. RGSZ1 in the cell lysates was immunoprecipitated using a specific RGSZ1 polyclonal antibody and protein A-Sepharose beads. The Gαi1 protein associated with RGSZ1 was probed with a monoclonal antibody against Gαi1 in a Western blot. As shown in Fig. 2, Gαi1 was only detected after immunoprecipitation with RGSZ1 antibody in the presence of AlF4− (lane 3). The amount of Gαi1 detected was increased when 1 μg of purified recombinant RGSZ1 protein was added in the cell lysate to increase the availability of RGSZ1 protein (lane 6). These data further indicated that the transition form of Gαi1 specifically interacts with RGSZ1. The interaction between RGSZ1 and Gαi1 was further examined in intact cells, using a yeast two-hybrid system functionally linked to a luciferase reporter gene. RGSZ1 was fused to the Gal4-AD, and Gαi1, Gαi1QL, Gαi2, and Gαi3 were fused with Gal4-BD. The RGSZ1-AD fusion protein was co-expressed with either Gαi1-BD, Gαi1Q204L-BD, Gαi2-BD, or Gαi3-BD fusion proteins and the luciferase reporter gene activity was determined. As shown in Fig. 3, transformants containing empty vectors alone (lane 1), RGSZ1-AD alone (lane 2), or Gαi-BD alone (lanes 3–6) had very low luciferase activity (∼5000 counts), indicating a low basal activity of the luciferase reporter. By comparison, the yeast strain containing both RGSZ1-AD and Gαi1-BD showed ∼70-fold increase (∼350,000 counts) over the luciferase activity of controls (lane 7), suggesting a strong interaction between RGSZ1 and Gαi1 in yeast. RGSZ1 also interacted well with the Gαi1Q204L mutant (lane 8) and Gαi3 (lane 10) in this system, but interacted poorly with Gαi2 (lane 9). To examine whether RGSZ1 functionally GAPs Gαi1, single-turnover GTPase assays were conducted using full-length recombinant RGSZ1-His6 and Gαi1-His6 proteins. In the GTPase assay, RGSZ1 dramatically accelerated the GTPase activity of Gαi1 in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 4A). 100 nm RGSZ1 maximally activated the GTP hydrolysis of 500 nmGαi1 in less than 1 min (Fig. 4B). TheKobs value was increased from 0.335 m−1 in the absence of RGSZ1 to 3.885 m−1 in the presence of RGSZ1 at 0 °C. By comparison, at 15 °C theKobs value was increased from 0.652 m−1 without RGSZ1 to 3.985 m−1 with RGSZ1 (Fig. 4B). The -fold stimulation by RGSZ1 on the Gαi1 GAP activity was minimized with longer reaction time because of the higher basal intrinsic GTPase activity. This was especially noted at 15 °C. To compare the relative GAP activities of RGSZ1 with other well known Gαi GAP proteins, the GAP activities of full-length GAIP and RGS4 core domain (residues 77–199) were also tested. The RGS4 core domain has been demonstrated to retain full GAP activity and binding affinity with the full-length protein in the in vitro assay (38Popov S. Yu K. Kozasa T. Wilkie T.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 7216-7220Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 4C, RGSZ1, GAIP, and RGS4 (core domain) in 20 nm each stimulated Gαi1 GTPase (200 nm) with similar rates. The observed rate constants (Kobs) for RGSZ1, GAIP, and RGS4 (core) indicated in Fig. 4C are 0.063, 0.069, and 0.056 s−1, respectively. A RGS7 core domain (residues 330–448) preferentially interacting with Gαo(29Posner B.A. Gilman A.G. Harris B.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31087-31093Google Scholar), showed relatively weaker activity toward Gαi1(Kobs = 0.024 s−1) (Fig. 4C). These data clearly indicate that RGSZ1 accelerates the GTPase of Gαi1 with almost identical activity to that observed for RGS4 and GAIP. Yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) G protein α subunit (GPA1) is a Gαi-like protein (39Dietzel C. Kurjan J. Cell. 1987; 50: 1001-1010Google Scholar, 40Miyajima I. Nakafuku M. Nakayama N. Brenner C. Miyajima A. Kaibuchi K. Arai K. Kaziro Y. Matsumoto K. Cell. 1987; 50: 1011-1019Google Scholar). Previous studies have shown that some mammalian RGS proteins, such as RGS4, RGS1, RGS3T, and RGS16, which interact well with mammalian Gαi proteins, can also modulate Gpa1 and attenuate the pheromone response in yeast (21Druey K.M. Blumer K.J. Kang V.H. Kehrl J.H. Nature. 1996; 379: 742-746Google Scholar, 41Chen C. Zheng B. Han J. Lin S.-C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 8679-8685Google Scholar). A functional complementation study was conducted to ascertain whether RGSZ1 could interact with Gpa1 and regulate the pheromone response pathway, as measured in a halo assay in the SST2 (a yeast RGS protein) knockout strain (Fig. 5). Treatment with α factor caused dose-dependent cell cycle arrest, as observed by the increase of the halo size in the empty vector control strain (Fig. 5A). By comparison, the α factor (100 μm)-induced halo in the RGSZ1-transformed strain was ∼70% smaller than that of the vector strain (Fig. 5B), suggesting that RGSZ1 partially blocked the pheromone response via modulation of Gpa1. SST2 (a positive control) showed stronger effects than RGSZ1 in the halo assay. However, RGS2, which has lower GAP activity for Gαi (32Heximer S.P. Srinivasa S.P. Bernstein L.S. Bernard J.L. Linder M.E. Hepler J.R. Blumer K.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 34253-34259Google Scholar, 37Heximer S.P. Watson N. Linder M.E. Blumer K.J. Hepler J.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 14389-14393Google Scholar, 41Chen C. Zheng B. Han J. Lin S.-C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 8679-8685Google Scholar), did not show a significant effect in modulating the yeast pheromone response. The α2A-adrenergic receptor (α2-AR) preferentially couples to Gαiproteins to transduce cellular signals (42Chabre O. Conklin B.R. Brandon S. Bourne H.R. Limbird L.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5730-5734Google Scholar). Activation of α2-AR results in MAPK activation in various cell types by coupling to Gαi. This activation is mediated by βγ subunits and occurs as a direct result of Ras activation (43Alblas J. van Corven E.J. Hordijk P.L. Milligan G. Moolenaar W.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22235-22238Google Scholar, 44Anderson N.G. Milligan G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 200: 1529-1535Google Scholar). RGS4 attenuates MAPK activation by interleukin 8 receptor and D2 dopamine receptor, both of which couple to Gαi proteins (21Druey K.M. Blumer K.J. Kang V.H. Kehrl J.H. Nature. 1996; 379: 742-746Google Scholar, 45Yan Y. Chi P.P. Bourne H.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11924-11927Google Scholar). The role of RGSZ1 in the regulation of the MAPK activity induced by activation of endogenous α2-AR in PC12 cells was examined. We generated PC12 stable cell lines expressing either the eGFP-RGSZ1 fusion protein or eGFP protein alone, with relatively identical expression levels (data not shown). As shown in Fig. 6, treatment of the eGFP cell line with UK14304, an agonist of α2-AR, caused a dose-dependent activation of p42/44 MAPK (ERK1/ERK2). The activation of MAPK induced by 10 μm UK14304 reached the maximal level in 5 min. By comparison, the activation of ERK1/2 by UK14304 was substantially blocked in the eGFP-RGSZ1 cell line. The activation of MAPK by UK14304 was also blocked by treatment with PTX (50 ng/ml) (data not shown), suggesting that UK14304-induced MAPK activation was mediated by PTX-sensitive Gαi protein, not by other endogenous PTX-insensitive Gα subunits, such as Gαz, Gαq, and Gαs, which may also weakly interact with the α2A receptor in PC12 cells (42Chabre O. Conklin B.R. Brandon S. Bourne H.R. Limbird L.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5730-5734Google Scholar). To further demonstrate the effect of RGSZ1 in attenuating another Gαi-coupled signal transduction pathway in mammalian cells, we transfected the RGSZ1 gene into CHO-K1 cells stably expressing the D2R, which is predominantly coupled to Gαisubunits. Toxoplasma gondii tachyzoites were fractionated by modification of an iodixanol density gradient method previously used for acidocalcisome isolation from Trypanosoma cruzi epimastigotes. Fractions were characterized using electron microscopy, x-ray microanalysis, and enzymatic markers, and it was demonstrated that the heaviest (pellet) fraction contains electron-dense vacuoles rich in phosphorus, calcium, and magnesium, as found before for acidocalcisomes. Staining with 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) indicated that poly- phosphate (polyP) was preferentially localized in this fraction together with pyrophosphate (PPi). Using an enzyme-based method, millimolar levels (in terms of Pi residues) of polyP chains of less than 50 residues long and micromolar levels in polyP chains of about 700–800 residues long were found to be preferentially localized in this fraction. The fraction also contained the pyrophosphatase and polyphosphatase activities characteristic of acidocalcisomes. Western blot analysis using antibodies against proteins from micronemes, dense granules, rhoptries, and plasma membrane showed that the acidocalcisomal fraction was not contaminated by these other organelles. T. gondii polyP levels rapidly decreased upon exposure of the parasites to a calcium ionophore (ionomycin), to an inhibitor of the V-H+-ATPase (bafilomycin A1), or to the alkalinizing agent NH4Cl. These changes were in parallel to an increase in intracellular Ca2+concentration, suggesting a close association between polyP hydrolysis and Ca2+ release from the acidocalcisome. These results provide a useful method for the isolation and characterization of acidocalcisomes, showing that they are distinct from other previously recognized organelles present in T. gondii, and provide evidence for the role of polyP metabolism in response to cellular stress. Not all these pumps and exchangers are necessarily present in all acidocalcisomes. However, the H+-PPase has been found in all cases in the purified organelle (11Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7712-7723Google Scholar, 12Scott D.A. de Souza W. Benchimol M. Zhong L. Lu H.-G. Moreno S.N.J. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 22151-22158Google Scholar, 13Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Biochem. J. 1999; 340: 759-766Google Scholar, 15Ruiz F.A. Marchesini N. Seufferheld M. Govindjee Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 46196-46203Google Scholar, 16Marchesini N. Ruiz F.A. Vieira M. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 8146-8153Google Scholar), which makes this pump the marker of choice for acidocalcisomes. The functions of the acidocalcisome in cell growth and survival are poorly understood. Based on its chemical composition, rich in PPi and polyP (a linear polymer of hundreds of orthophosphate residues linked by high energy phosphoanhydride bonds), one possible function could be as an energy and phosphate reservoir. PolyP has been shown to have a function in the cellular response to nutrient limitation during the stationary phase of growth and in the chelation of metals (17Kulaev I.S. Kulakovskaya T.C. Andreeva N.A. Lichko L.P. Prog. Mol. Subcell. Biol. 1999; 23: 27-43Google Scholar, 18Kuroda A. Tanaka S. Ikeda T. Kato J. Takiguchi N. Ohtake H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 14264-14269Google Scholar, 19Kornberg A. J. Bacteriol. 1995; 177: 491-496Google Scholar). A critical role for the acidocalcisomal polyP in the adaptation processes of Trypanosoma cruzi to environmental changes has been demonstrated (20Ruiz F.A. Rodrigues C.O. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 26114-26121Google Scholar). In several protozoan parasites it has been shown that the acidocalcisome is the main calcium storage compartment (1Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Parasitol. Today. 1999; 15: 443-448Google Scholar, 2Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 33: 151-159Google Scholar). Because Ca2+ signaling is involved in many processes, such as invasion of host cells by different parasites (2Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 33: 151-159Google Scholar, 21Vieira M. Moreno S.N.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2000; 106: 157-162Google Scholar), it is possible, although it has not yet been demonstrated, that this compartment could also have a role as a source of releasable Ca2+. Many aspects of acidocalcisomes, such as their transport and enzymatic activities, need further study to understand the physiological importance of these organelles in protozoan parasites. A crucial requirement for these studies is the isolation of the organelles free from interference of other organelles or enzymatic activities. In the present work, we report a modification of the cell fractionation method used for T. cruzi epimastigotes (22Scott D.A. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 24215-24221Google Scholar) for the purification of acidocalcisomes from Toxoplasma gondii tachyzoites. We also report for the first time the determination of short and long chain polyP in these parasites. Our results indicate that the concentration of polyP changes drastically under alkaline stress or when the cells are incubated with calcium ionophores. Ca2+ release from acidocalcisomes is associated with the hydrolysis of polyP. Tachyzoites of T. gondii RH strain were cultivated and purified by the method of Moreno and Zhong (5Moreno S.N.J. Zhong L. Biochem. J. 1996; 313: 655-659Google Scholar) in bovine turbinate cells (ATCC CRL 1390). Host cells were cultivated in tissue culture flasks using Dulbecco's minimum essential medium supplemented with 10% horse serum. Cells were infected with tachyzoites at a final host-to-parasite ratio of 1:5. Parasites were harvested 2–3 days after infection and purified as described previously (23Chamberland S. Kirst H.A. Current W.L. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1991; 35: 903-909Google Scholar). Horse serum, DNase, RNase, Dulbecco's minimum essential medium (D5523), Dulbecco's phosphate buffer saline (PBS), Hanks' solution, nocodazole, sodium orthovanadate, sodium pyrophosphate, silicon carbide (400 mesh), protease inhibitors mixture, and goat anti-mouse antibodies labeled with horseradish peroxidase were purchased from Sigma. Bafilomycin A1 was from Kamiya Biomedicals, Thousand Oaks, CA. Iodixanol (Optiprep, Nycomed) was from Invitrogen. 2-Amino-6-mercapto-7-methylpurine ribonucleoside and purine nucleoside phosphorylase (these two components were from the EnzChek phosphate assay kit) and the tetraacetoxymethyl esters of fura 2 (1-[2-(5-carboxyoxazol-2-yl)-6-aminobenzofuran-5-oxyl]-2-(2′-amino-5′-methylphenoxy)-ethane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid) and BCECF (2′,7′-bis-(carboxyethyl)-5(and-6)-carboxyfluorescein), fura 2-AM and BCECF-AM, respectively, were from Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR. The enhanced chemiluminescence detection kit was fromAmersham Biosciences. Coomassie Blue protein assay reagent was from Bio-Rad. Aminomethylenediphosphonate was synthesized by Michael Martin in the laboratory of Dr. Eric Oldfield at the Department of Chemistry, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. [14-C]Inulin was from PerkinElmer Life Sciences. The antibodies used for the characterization of the subcellular fractions were: anti-SAG1 monoclonal antibody, a gift from Dr. John Boothroyd, Stanford University School of Medicine; anti-ROP monoclonal antibody, a gift from Dr. Jean Francois Dubremetz, Institut de Biologie, CNRS; and anti-micronemes and anti-dense granules, gifts from Dr. David Sibley, Washington University. Escherichia coli strain CA38 pTrcPPX1 was kindly provided by Prof. Arthur Kornberg, Stanford University School of Medicine (Stanford, CA). All other reagents were analytical grade. Tachyzoites (∼2.4 × 1010 cells) were centrifuged at 500 × gfor 10 min, and the cell pellet was washed twice with Dulbecco's PBS and once in lysis buffer (125 mm sucrose, 50 mmKCl, 4 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mm EDTA, 20 mm K-Hepes, 5 mm dithiothreitol, protease inhibitors mixture (0.2% v/v), 12 μg/ml DNase, 12 μg/ml RNase, and 8 μg/ml nocodazole, pH 7.2). The cell pellet was mixed with 1.8× wet weight silicon carbide and lysed by grinding with a pestle and mortar for not more than 60 s (lysis was checked by microscopy every 15 s). The mixture of silicon carbide and lysed cells was resuspended in ∼100 ml of lysis buffer, and the suspension was left for 3 min on ice to allow most of the silicon carbide to settle. The liquid phase was carefully transferred to another tube and centrifuged at 36 × g for 5 min. The supernatant was collected and left on ice, whereas the pellet was resuspended in ∼50 ml of lysis buffer and centrifuged again under the same conditions. Combined supernatants were centrifuged at 144 × g for 10 min to remove debris and unbroken cells. The supernatant obtained from this last centrifugation was centrifuged at 15,000 × g for 10 min. The pellet was resuspended in 2.7 ml of lysis buffer, homogenized with the aid of a 22-gauge needle about 8–10 times until no clumps were observed, and mixed with 1.3 ml of 60% iodixanol. This mixture (20% iodixanol) was included as the middle layer of a discontinuous gradient, with the other (4-ml) steps containing 10, 15, 25, and 30% iodixanol (diluted in lysis buffer). The gradient was centrifuged at 50,000 × g using a Beckman SW 28 rotor for 60 min. Thirteen fractions were collected corresponding to bands and interfaces (Fig. 1). The acidocalcisomal fraction (F13) pelleted on the bottom of the tube and was resuspended in lysis buffer. All these procedures were done at 4 °C. ATPases, pyrophosphatase, and exopolyphosphatase activities were assayed by measuring phosphate release using the EnzCheck phosphate assay kit as described before (11Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7712-7723Google Scholar, 12Scott D.A. de Souza W. Benchimol M. Zhong L. Lu H.-G. Moreno S.N.J. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 22151-22158Google Scholar, 13Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Biochem. J. 1999; 340: 759-766Google Scholar) with the microtiter plate modification (11Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7712-7723Google Scholar). Acid phosphatase (lysosome marker, Ref. 24Barrett A.J. Heath M.F. Dingle J.T. Lysosomes: A Laboratory Handbook. 2nd Ed. Elsevier/North-Holland Biomedical Press, Amsterdam1977: 36-40Google Scholar) was assayed in microtiter plates by measuring phosphate release from p-nitrophenylphosphate. Fractions (5 μl) were added to a 50-μl reaction mixture containing 0.1 m sodium acetate, pH 5.5, and 10 mm p-nitrophenylphosphate and incubated for 30 min at 28 °C. Reactions were stopped by the addition of 150 mm sodium hydroxide (100 μl), and released p-nitrophenol was detected at 405 nm. Protein was determined using the Bio-Rad Coomassie Blue method. All assays were recorded in a PowerWave 340i plate reader (Bio-Tek Instruments). Polyphosphatase activity was determined measuring Pi release in the presence and absence of polyP. Samples were incubated for 5 min at 30 °C with 60 mmTris-HCl, pH 7.5, 6.0 mm MgCl2, and 520 μm purified polyP500–700 in a final volume of 75 μl. One unit corresponded to the release of 1 pmol of Pi per min. Release of Pi was monitored by the method of Lanzetta et al. (25Lanzetta P.A. Alvarez L.J. Reinach P.S. Candia O.A. Anal. Biochem. 1979; 100: 95-97Google Scholar). PolyP500–700was isolated from agarose gels with Maddrell salt solution as described Clark and Wood (26Clark J.E. Wood H.G. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 161: 280-290Google Scholar). The construction of normalized density distribution histograms was carried out as described before (15Ruiz F.A. Marchesini N. Seufferheld M. Cells (∼5 × 107) obtained as described above were washed twice with Dulbecco's PBS. The pellet was resuspended in 2 ml of the same buffer, and 45 μl of this suspension was incubated at room temperature with 10 μg of 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI)/ml. After 10 min, the samples were mounted on a slide and observed with an Olympus Fluoview FV300 laser-scanning confocal microscope using optical sections of 0.1 μm and an argon laser for detection of polyP (20Ruiz F.A. Rodrigues C.O. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 26114-26121Google Scholar). Acidocalcisomal fractions (0.5 mg of protein/ml) were incubated with DAPI as described above, and samples were observed with an epifluorescence microscope using an Olympus WIG filter (excitation 380–385 nm; emission >580 nm) for polyP detection. Recombinant exopolyphosphatase (rPPX1) was obtained and purified as described before (20Ruiz F.A. Rodrigues C.O. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 26114-26121Google Scholar) from E. coli strain CA38 pTrcPPX1. This strain of bacteria is insertionally inactivated for endogenous polyphosphate kinase and exopolyphosphatase (27Crooke E. Akiyama M. Rao N.N. Kornberg A. J. Biol. Proteins from each fraction of the gradient were separated by SDS-PAGE and blotted onto nitrocellulose (NitroPure, MSI, Westborough, MA) with a Bio-Rad Transblot apparatus by standard techniques. Blots were blocked overnight at 4 °C in 5% nonfat dry milk in Dulbecco's PBS, washed 3 times (10 min each) in Dulbecco's PBS containing 0.1% Tween 20 (T-PBS), and incubated for 1 h at room temperature with primary antibodies against micronemes (6D10 for MIC-2) (29Wan K.L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Google Scholar), rhoptries (T3–4A71C8 for ROP 2, 3, 4) (30Leriche M.A. Dubremetz J.F. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1991; 45: 249-259Google Scholar), dense granules (4G1 for GRA4) (31Labruyere E. Lingnau M. Mercier C. Sibley L.D. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1999; 102: 311-324Google Scholar), and plasma membrane (SAG1) (32Bülow R. Boothroyd J.C. J. Immunol. 1991; 147: 3496-3500Google Scholar), diluted according to the Fig. 5 legend. Kim Y. Poole R.J. Rea P.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 1775-1779Google Scholar). Membranes were then washed 3 times with T-PBS (15 min each) and incubated for 30 min with horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-mouse IgG diluted 1:10,000 (or 1:2,000 anti-rabbit IgG when the anti V-H+-PPase antibody was used). After another round of washes (4 times with T-PBS/15 min each), the membranes were processed for chemiluminescence detection as per the manufacturer's (Amersham Biosciences) instructions. Before reprobing with other antibodies, blots were stripped for 30 min at 50 °C in 62.5 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, containing 2% SDS and 1% 2-mercaptoethanol and washed 3 times with T-PBS before the incubations. For observation of acidocalcisomal fraction 13, the sample was washed twice in 250 mm sucrose and diluted before being applied to Formvar-coated copper or nickel grids. Vierkotter S. Oldfield E. Payares G. Sanoja C. Bailey B.N. Yan W. Scott D.A. Moreno S.N.J. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 33609-33615Google Scholar). The intracellular concentration of polyP was calculated taking into account the cell volume of tachyzoites measured by the [14C]inulin exclusion method as previously described by Damper and Patton (36Damper D. Patton C.L. J. Protozool. 1976; 23: 349-356Google Scholar), with some modifications. Cells were washed twice in Hanks' balanced salt solution (HBSS) supplemented with 0.1% (w/v) glucose and 0.05% (w/v) albumin (HBSSA) and then resuspended in HBSSA containing 0.2 mg/ml [14C]inulin at final concentrations of 1 × 109 and 2 × 109 cells/ml. Three 50-μl aliquots were taken from each suspension and transferred to scintillation vials. The suspensions were then centrifuged in Eppendorf tubes at 14,000 × g for 2 min, and three 50-μl aliquots of the supernatant were transferred to scintillation vials. 5 ml of scintillation mixture was added to each vial, and the vials were counted. All cell manipulations were performed on ice and/or with chilled solutions. Cell volume was determined by inulin exclusion. The difference in radioactivity/ml between the cell suspension and the supernatant was used to calculate the cell volume (difference divided by radioactivity of supernatant = fraction of volume occupied by cells). Results were expressed as an average of the values obtained in two different suspensions from three independent experiments. Spectrofluorometric determinations of tachyzoites loaded with fura 2-AM or BCECF-AM were performed as described previously (5Moreno S.N.J. Zhong L. Biochem. J. 1996; 313: 655-659Google Scholar). For the alkaline or ionophore treatments, tachyzoites (2.5 × 108) were washed once with Dulbecco's PBS and resuspended in 0.55 ml of 116 mm NaCl, 5.4 mm KCl, 0.8 mm MgSO4, 5.5 mm glucose, 1 mm EGTA, and 50 mmHepes pH 7.4 (buffer A). At the times indicated, 40 mmNH4Cl, 1 μm ionomycin, or 1 μmbafilomycin were added. Aliquots of 50 μl were withdrawn at the times indicated and mixed with 500 μl of guanidine isothiocyanate lysis buffer (20Ruiz F.A. Rodrigues C.O. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 26114-26121Google Scholar) for long chain polyP determination or with 300 μl of ice-cold 0.5 m HClO4 for short chain polyP determination as described above. The method used to isolate acidocalcisomes from various protozoa has been improved in stages (11Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7712-7723Google Scholar, 12Scott D.A. de Souza W. Benchimol M. Zhong L. Lu H.-G. Moreno S.N.J. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 22151-22158Google Scholar, 13Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Docampo R. Biochem. J. 1999; 340: 759-766Google Scholar, 22Scott D.A. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 24215-24221Google Scholar) but has not proved useful for isolation of these organelles from apicomplexan parasites. A new procedure for the isolation of acidocalcisomes fromT. gondii is depicted in Fig. 1. This method used generally lower concentrations of iodixanol in the gradient steps than those previously used for the purification of acidocalcisomes from T. cruziepimastigotes (22Scott D.A. Docampo R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 24215-24221Google Scholar) but with the T. gondii sample added in the middle of the gradient in a 20% iodixanol layer rather than applied to the top of the gradient without added iodixanol. This strategy allowed a better separation of the acidocalcisomes from the ghosts present in the intermediate fractions and a better recovery of the pellet fraction at the base of the gradient (fraction 13). When directly applied to Formvar-coated grids and observed by electron microscopy (Fig. 2B), fraction 13 was seen to contain electron-dense structures, as expected for acidocalcisomes (1Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Parasitol. Today. 1999; 15: 443-448Google Scholar, 2Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 33: 151-159Google Scholar). The same electron-dense organelles were observed in whole cells when they were applied to EM grids in the same manner (Fig. 2A). X-ray microanalysis of the granules present in fraction 13 (Fig. 3) showed that they have the same chemical composition as acidocalcisomes found in other protozoa (1Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Parasitol. Today. 1999; 15: 443-448Google Scholar, 2Docampo R. Moreno S.N.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 33: 151-159Google Scholar) and electron-dense vacuoles in whole T. gondii (9Luo S. Vieira M. Graves J. Zhong L. Moreno S.N.J. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 55-66Google Scholar), indicating that they are acidocalcisomes.Figure 3X-ray microanalysis spectra of acidocalcisomes isolated from T. gondii(A) and background (B).Peaks from Cu and Si arise from the grids and the silicon carbide used for cell disruption, respectively.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) The distribution of different enzymatic activities and organelle markers was compared along with that of the established marker for acidocalcisomes, H+-PPase (Figs.4 and 5). The aminomethylenediphosphonate-sensitive pyrophosphatase activity peaks in three different regions along the gradient (Fig. 4). Observation of these fractions by electron microscopy showed that the only fraction containing the electron-dense vacuoles, as seen in Fig. 2B, was fraction 13. Fractions 1 and 5 contained many cell ghosts produced in the lysis procedure (data not shown). A V-H+-ATPase sensitive to bafilomycin has been described to be present in acidocalcisomes of T. gondii (5Moreno S.N.J. Zhong L. Biochem. J. 1996; 313: 655-659Google Scholar, 6Moreno S.N.J. Zhong L. Lu H.-G. de Souza W. Benchimol M. Biochem. J. 1997; 330: 853-860Google Scholar). However, the V-H+-ATPase activity seems to have a broader distribution if compared with the H+-PPase (Fig. 4). Acid phosphatase activity, a marker for another acidic organelle, the lysosome, did not peak in fraction 13 (Fig. 4). The acidocalcisomal fraction also lacks markers for other organelles present in T. gondii, such as rhoptries (30Leriche M.A. Dubremetz J.F. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1991; 45: 249-259Google Scholar), micronemes (29Wan K.L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Google Scholar), and dense granules (31Labruyere E. Lingnau M. Mercier C. Sibley L.D. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1999; 102: 311-324Google Scholar), as depicted in the Western blots shown in Fig. 5. Likewise, antibodies against the surface antigen of T. gondii tachyzoites (SAG1) (32Bülow R. Boothroyd J.C. J. Immunol. 1991; 147: 3496-3500Google Scholar) show that the plasma membrane is distributed mainly in the middle of the gradient (Fig. 5). Antibodies against the H+-PPase (Fig. 5) confirm the distribution of this protein, obtained by enzymatic measurements (shown in Fig. 4). The strong reaction of this antibody in fractions 4–12 is because of the presence of plasma membrane fragments (as marked by SAG1) and the high amount of protein in these fractions (Fig 4). The H+-PPase has been previously shown to be located on the cell surface of T. gondii as well as in acidocalcisomes (7Rodrigues C.O. Scott D.A. Bailey B.N. de Souza W. Benchimol M. Moreno B. Urbina J.A. Oldfield E. Moreno S.N.J. Biochem. J. 2000; 349: 737-745Google Scholar). Importantly though, fraction 13, which contains low amounts of protein, showed a clear reaction with antibodies against the H+-PPase and no reaction with antibodies against all other markers, thus indicating that this fraction contained only acidocalcisomes. T. gondii tachyzoites contain high levels of long and short chain polyP, as determined by measuring degradation of polyP with recombinant yeast exopolyphosphatase (rPPX1). Cellular concentrations of short chain polyP (less than 50 phosphate residues) were in the mm range (in terms of Pi residues, 24.0 ± 0.5 mm), whereas values for long chain polyP (700–800 phosphate residues) were in the micromolar range (43.0 ± 0.5 μm), taking into account a calculated cell volume of 16.5 ± 3 μl/109 tachyzoites. Tachyzoites also contained very high levels of PPi (7.95 ± 0.16 mm). Controls of uninfected

Laminin-6 (LN6) and laminin-5 (LN5), which share the common integrin-binding domain in the laminin α3 chain, are thought to cooperatively regulate cellular functions, but the former has poorly been characterized. Human fibrosarcoma HT1080 cells expressing an exogenous α3 chain were found to secrete LN6 with the full-length α3 chain and a smaller amount of its processed form lacking the carboxyl-terminal G4-5 domain, besides mature LN5 without G4-5 (mat-LN5). We prepared the unprocessed LN6 and mat-LN5, as well as LN6 mutants without G4-5 (LN6ΔG4-5) or G5 (LN6ΔG5). These laminins supported attachment of HT1080 cells and human keratinocytes (HaCaT) through integrins α3β1 and/or α6β1. LN6ΔG4-5, LN6ΔG5, and mat-LN5 promoted rapid cell spreading, whereas LN6 did hardly. A purified G4-5 fragment of the laminin α3 chain supported cell attachment through interaction with heparan sulfate proteoglycans and promoted cell spreading in combination with mat-LN5 or LN6ΔG4-5. These results imply that the G4-5 domain within the LN6 molecule suppresses cell adhesion, while the released G4-5 promotes it. The presence of G5 rather than the heparin-binding domain G4 was responsible for the impaired cell spreading activity of LN6. However, the unprocessed LN6 promoted cell spreading in the presence of mat-LN5. Unlike mat-LN5, both LN6ΔG4-5 and LN6 did weakly or did not stimulate cell motility. These findings demonstrate that LN6 and LN5 have distinct biological activities, but they may cooperatively support cell adhesion. The proteolytic processing of the α3 chain seems to regulate the physiological functions of LN6.
