The components of basement membranes not only support tissue architectures but also regulate various cellular functions, such as adhesion, migration, differentiation, growth, and apoptosis. The regulatory functions of basement membranes can be largely attributed to the interaction of laminins with their receptors. Genetically distinct five α, three β, and three γ subunits of laminin form specialized heterotrimers (laminins-1 to -15) that are expressed in a tissue-specific manner during embryonic development as well as in the adult (1Colognato H. Yurchenco P.D. Dev. Dyn. 2000; 218: 213-234Crossref PubMed Scopus (1050) Google Scholar). All laminin α subunits share a large globular domain at their carboxyl-terminal region (G domain), which consists of five homologous globular subdomains (or modules) of about 200 amino acids each (G1–G5 or LG1–LG5). This region contains binding sites for extracellular matrix proteins (e.g. perlecan and fibulin-1), as well as cellular receptors including integrins, syndecans, and α-dystroglycan (1Colognato H. Yurchenco P.D. Dev. Dyn. 2000; 218: 213-234Crossref PubMed Scopus (1050) Google Scholar). Laminin-5 (LN5), 1The abbreviations used are: LNx, laminin-x; HSPG, heparansulfate proteoglycan; mat-LN5, mature LN5 without G4-5 domain of laminin α3 chain; LN6ΔGx, LN6 lacking Gx domain of laminin α3 chain; α3G4-5, a G4-5 fragment of laminin α3 chain which consists of α3, β3, and γ2 chains, was originally found as an anchoring filament component of keratinocytes (kalinin/epiligrin/nicein) (2Rousselle P. Lunstrum G.P. Keene D.R. Burgeson R.E. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 114: 567-576Crossref PubMed Scopus (658) Google Scholar, 3Carter W.G. Ryan M.C. Gahr P.J. Cell. 1991; 65: 599-610Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (670) Google Scholar, 4Verrando P. Pisani A. Ortonne J.P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 942: 45-56Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar) and as a cell-scattering factor secreted by gastric carcinoma cells (ladsin) (5Miyazaki K. Kikkawa Y. Nakamura A. Yasumitsu H. Umeda M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 11767-11771Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar). LN5 is unique in its biological activity and structure. It potently stimulates both cell adhesion and cell motility in culture (5Miyazaki K. Kikkawa Y. Nakamura A. Yasumitsu H. Umeda M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 11767-11771Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 6Kikkawa Y. Umeda M. Miyazaki K. J. Biochem. 1994; 116: 862-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 7Rousselle P. Aumailley M. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 125: 205-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). LN5 is currently the only laminin molecule with truncations in the amino-terminal regions (or the short arms) of all three subunits. The laminin β3 and γ2 subunits are found only in LN5, whereas the α3 chain is found in laminin-6 (LN6, α3β1γ1), laminin-7 (LN7, α3β2γ1), and laminin-13 (LN13, α3β2γ3). LN5 is secreted by various types of epithelial cells in tissues and in culture, and assembled into the basement membrane structures in vivo. The interaction of LN5 with integrin α6β4 in the hemidesmosome structures is essential for stable attachment of basal cells to their substrate, polarization of the epithelial sheet, and stabilization of cellular architecture through the intermediate filament (2Rousselle P. Lunstrum G.P. Keene D.R. Burgeson R.E. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 114: 567-576Crossref PubMed Scopus (658) Google Scholar, 3Carter W.G. Ryan M.C. Gahr P.J. Cell. 1991; 65: 599-610Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (670) Google Scholar). LN5 is synthesized and secreted in a precursor form containing a 190-kDa α3, a 140-kDa β3, and a 150-kDa γ2 chains, but the α3 and γ2 chains undergo proteolytic processing to smaller species of 160 kDa and 105 kDa, respectively (8Marinkovich M.P. Lunstrum G.P. Burgeson R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17900-17906Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recent studies suggest that post-translational processing of LN5 molecules modulates their function. Proteolytic cleavage of the γ2 chain by MMP-2 (gelatinase A) or MT1-MMP increases the cell motility activity of LN5 (9Giannelli G. Falk-Marzillier J. Schiraldi O. Stetler-Stevenson W.G. Quaranta V. Science. 1997; 277: 225-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (1042) Google Scholar, 10Koshikawa N. Giannelli G. Cirulli V. Miyazaki K. Quaranta V. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 148: 615-624Crossref PubMed Scopus (555) Google Scholar) but decreases the cell adhesion activity (11Gagnoux-Palacios L. Allegra M. Spirito F. Pommeret O. Romero C. Ortonne J.P. Meneguzzi G. J. Cell Biol. 2001; 153: 835-850Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Similarly, it has been reported that the processing of the 190-kDa α3 chain to the 160-kDa one by plasmin converts the precursor LN5 from a migration ligand to an anchorage ligand in hemidesmosomes (12Goldfinger L.E. Stack M.S. Jones J.C. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 141: 255-265Crossref PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). However, the mature LN5 with the processed α3 chain has been shown to strongly promote cell motility or cell scattering via integrin α3β1 (5Miyazaki K. Kikkawa Y. Nakamura A. Yasumitsu H. Umeda M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 11767-11771Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 6Kikkawa Y. Umeda M. Miyazaki K. J. Biochem. 1994; 116: 862-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). It was recently found that the cleavage of the α3 chain occurs between the G3 and G4 domains, releasing the G4-5 fragment (13Tsubota Y. Mizushima H. Hirosaki T. Higashi S. Yasumitsu H. Miyazaki K. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 278: 614-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar), and that the G3 domain is essential for the potent activity of LN5 to promote cell adhesion and migration (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). It has also been found that the G2 domain contains an integrin α3β1 binding sequence (15Mizushima H. Takamura H. Miyagi Y. Kikkawa Y. Yamanaka N. Yasumitsu H. Misugi K. Miyazaki K. Cell Growth Differ. 1997; 8: 979-987PubMed Google Scholar). Taken together, these past studies indicate that the G1-3 domain of the α3 chain is the primary site to bind cell surface receptors, but the short arms of the γ2 and possibly β3 chains are likely to affect the biological activity of LN5. To clarify the structure and function relationship of LN5, it seems important to characterize LN6, because these two laminins share the common α3 subunit and are often produced by the same cell types. LN6 was first identified as k-laminin in culture media of human keratinocytes and a squamous cell carcinoma line (8Marinkovich M.P. Lunstrum G.P. Burgeson R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17900-17906Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Marinkovich M.P. Lunstrum G.P. Keene D.R. Burgeson R.E. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 695-703Crossref PubMed Scopus (235) Google Scholar). In human amnion, about half-amount of LN5 exists in complexes with LN6 or LN7 (17Champliaud M.F. Lunstrum G.P. Rousselle P. Nishiyama T. Keene D.R. Burgeson R.E. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 1189-1198Crossref PubMed Scopus (228) Google Scholar). The rotary-shadowed image analysis of the complexes suggests that LN5 binds with LN6 or LN7 through the interaction of their short arms. It is assumed that the complex formation allows stable association of LN5 with the basement membrane in the amnion (17Champliaud M.F. Lunstrum G.P. Rousselle P. Nishiyama T. Keene D.R. Burgeson R.E. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 1189-1198Crossref PubMed Scopus (228) Google Scholar). However, no previous studies have shown the biological activity of LN6 or LN7 presumably because of the difficulty in isolating these laminins in LN5-free forms. In the present study, we isolated LN6 as an unprocessed single protein and as truncated forms lacking the G4-5, G3-5, or G5 domain of the α3 chain. This report describes the biological activities of the four forms of LN6, as well as their differences from LN5. Human fibrosarcoma cell line HT1080 was obtained from Japanese Cancer Resources Bank (Tokyo, Japan). Four transfectants of HT1080 cells, HT1080/WT, HT1080/ΔG5, HT1080/ΔG4-5, and HT1080/ΔG3-5 were established in our recent study (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). HT1080/WT has been stably transfected with a full-length cDNA of human laminin α3 subunit, and HT1080/ΔG5, HT1080/ΔG4-5, and HT1080/ΔG3-5 with mutant cDNAs for the laminin α3 chains lacking the G5, G4-5, and G3-5 domains, respectively. Buffalo rat liver-derived epithelial cell line BRL has been described in our previous studies (5Miyazaki K. Kikkawa Y. Nakamura A. Yasumitsu H. Umeda M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 11767-11771Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). These cell lines were maintained in a 1:1 mixture of Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium: Ham's F12 medium (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F12) (Invitrogen) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, penicillin, and streptomycin sulfate. A spontaneously immortalized human keratinocyte cell line, HaCaT (18Boukamp P. Petrussevska R.T. Breitkreutz D. Hornung J. Markham A. Fusenig N.E. J. Cell Biol. 1988; 106: 761-771Crossref PubMed Scopus (3476) Google Scholar), was a generous gift from Dr. N. E. Fusenig (Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany). HaCaT cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium. Mouse monoclonal antibodies against human laminin α3 chain (LSα3c4) and γ2 chain (D4B5) were previously established and characterized (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 19Mizushima H. Koshikawa N. Moriyama K. Takamura H. Nagashima Y. Hirahara F. Miyazaki K. Horm. Res. 1998; 50: 7-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). A rabbit polyclonal antibody against the G4 domain of laminin α3 chain was produced in our laboratory (13Tsubota Y. Mizushima H. Hirosaki T. Higashi S. Yasumitsu H. Miyazaki K. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 278: 614-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Other antibodies used and their sources are: a mouse monoclonal antibody specific for human laminin β3 chain from Transduction Laboratories (Lexington, KY); a rat monoclonal antibody against laminin β1 chain (VNR147) and mouse monoclonal antibodies against human laminin γ1 chain (2E8) and against human integrin α5 (P1D6) and β1 (6S6) subunits from Chemicon International Inc. (Temecula, CA); mouse monoclonal antibodies against integrin α2 (P1E6) and α3 (P1B5) subunits from Invitrogen; and a rat monoclonal antibody against human integrin α6 (G0H3) from BD PharMingen (San Diego, CA). Mouse EHS-laminin (laminin-1, LN1), human laminin-10/11 (LN10/11), and human plasma fibronectin were purchased from Transduction Laboratories, Invitrogen, and Asahi Technoglass (Tokyo, Japan), respectively. Various recombinant LN5 forms have been isolated from the conditioned media of HT1080 transfectants (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). In the present study, LN5 and three forms of LN6 were purified by basically the same method as before. Briefly, the serum-free conditioned medium of HT1080/WT cells was fractionated by molecular-sieve chromatography on a Sepharose-4B column (AmershamBiosciences) and then by a heparin-Sepharose column. Proteins bound to the heparin column were eluted with 0.5 m NaCl and then with 1.0 m NaCl. Each fraction was passed through a gelatin-Sepharose column to remove fibronectin, and then subjected to two kinds of immunoaffinity chromatographies. LN5 was purified from the 0.5 m NaCl eluate using a LSα3c4-Sepharose (anti-α3 chain antibody) column and a D4B5-Sepharose (anti-γ2 chain antibody) column as reported previously (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). To isolate LN6, the 1.0m NaCl eluate from the heparin column was diluted 10-fold to decrease the NaCl concentration, and then applied to a Q-Sepharose HPLC column (Amersham Biosciences). The materials eluted between 0.3 and 0.4 m NaCl were passed through the D4B5-Sepharose column to remove LN5. Finally, the unbound materials were applied to the LSα3c4-Sepharose immunoaffinity column. Bound LN6 was eluted with 0.05% trifluoroacetic acid and immediately neutralized. LN6 mutants without the G5 domain of laminin α3 chain (LN6ΔG5), without the G4-5 domain (LN6ΔG4-5), and without the G3-5 domain (LN6ΔG3-5) were purified from the conditioned media of HT1080/ΔG5, HT1080/ΔG4-5, and HT1080/ΔG3-5 cells, respectively, by essentially the same procedure as above. The G4-5 fragment of laminin α3 chain (α3G4-5) was isolated according to the recently published procedure with some modifications (13Tsubota Y. Mizushima H. Hirosaki T. Higashi S. Yasumitsu H. Miyazaki K. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 278: 614-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Briefly, the concentrated conditioned medium of HT1080/WT cells was fractionated on a Sepharose 4B column and then on a heparin-Sepharose column. Proteins bound to the heparin column at 0.1 m NaCl were eluted sequentially with 0.4, 0.6, and 0.8 m NaCl. The α3G4-5 fragment was mostly eluted at 0.8 m NaCl, and this fraction was finally applied to a cation-exchange Mono S HPLC column at 0.1 m NaCl. The α3G4-5 fragment was eluted from the column at 0.5∼0.6 m NaCl. SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and immunoblotting were performed as described previously (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Two-dimensional SDS-PAGE analysis was performed according to the method reported before (20Koshikawa N. Moriyama K. Takamura H. Mizushima H. Nagashima Y. Yanoma S. Miyazaki K. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 5596-5601PubMed Google Scholar). The first dimensional SDS-PAGE was carried out on a 4% polyacrylamide disc gel (2 mm in diameter and 70 mm in length) under non-reducing conditions. After the electrophoresis, the gel was incubated in a SDS sample buffer containing 5% 2-mercaptoethanol at room temperature for 15 min, placed on a 6% polyacrylamide slab gel (85-mm wide, 1-mm thick, and 70-mm long), and run for the second dimensional SDS-PAGE. Proteins separated on the slab gel were subsequently subjected to the immunoblotting procedure. The cell attachment assay was performed as described previously (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). 96-well microtiter plates (Corning Costar, Acton, MA) were coated with various substrates in Ca2+- and Mg2+-free phosphate-buffered saline at 4 °C overnight, and then blocked with phosphate-buffered saline containing 1.2% (w/v) bovine serum albumin at 37 °C for 1.5 h. Cells were suspended in serum-free medium at a density of 2∼4 × 105 cells/ml, and 100-μl aliquots were inoculated onto the plates. After incubation at 37 °C, adherent cells were fixed with 2.5% glutaraldehyde and stained with 0.0005% Hoechst 33342, 0.001% Triton X-100 for 1.5 h. The fluorescent intensity of each well of the plates was measured using a CytoFluor 2350 fluorometer (Millipore, Bedford, MA). A blank value corresponding to an empty well was automatically subtracted. Cell scattering activity of various forms of laminins toward BRL cells was assayed as reported previously (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Cells were plated at a density of 7,000 cells/well onto 24-well plates (Sumibe Medical, Tokyo, Japan) containing 0.5 ml/well of Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F12 plus 1% fetal bovine serum. In the standard assay, test samples were directly added into the culture and incubated at 37 °C. After 2 days, cell scattering was judged by microscopic observation. Alternatively, test samples were coated on 24-well plates as described above, and the plates were used for assays of cell scattering and cell migration. Cell migration on these substrates was monitored at 37 °C with a time-lapse video. The length of cell migration was measured with a video micrometer (VM-30; Olympus, Tokyo, Japan). It was previously found that when a cDNA for human laminin α3 chain is transfected into human fibrosarcoma cell line HT1080, the exogenous α3 chain is assembled with the endogenous β3 and γ2 chains to produce the LN5 hetrotrimer of α3β3γ2 (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). In that study, the conditioned medium of the HT1080 transfectant (HT1080/WT) contained both the 190-kDa and 160-kDa α3 chains, but only the LN5 with the 160-kDa α3 chain, which had been proteolytically cleaved between the G3 and G4 domains, was purified from the conditioned medium. Antibodies to the laminin β3 chain and to the γ2 chain precipitated the 160-kDa α3 chain but not the 190-kDa one from the conditioned medium, suggesting the presence of α3-containing laminin(s) other than LN5. In the present study, the conditioned medium of HT1080/WT cells was analyzed by two-dimensional SDS-PAGE and the following immunoblotting with the antibodies to the laminin α3, γ2, β1, and γ1 chains. On the first dimensional non-reducing SDS-PAGE, the α3 chain was separated into at least four different molecular sizes, over 1,000 kDa (the top of gel), 600, 450, and 400 kDa (Fig.1 A). The 450- and 400-kDa α3 chains were associated with the γ2 chain, showing that they were the LN5 forms with the 150- and 105-kDa γ2 chains, respectively (Fig.1 B). This demonstrated that the 190-kDa α3 chain had completely been converted to the 160-kDa mature form in LN5 molecule. On the other hand, the α3 chain in the 600-kDa complex was not associated with the γ2 chain (Fig. 1 B). On the second dimensional reducing SDS-PAGE, the α3 chain at this position was separated into a 190-kDa major spot and a 160-kDa minor one. Laminin β1 and γ1 chains were separated as broad bands, showing that they existed as different complexes including the β1-γ1 heterodimer (Fig. 1, C and D). The β1 and γ1 chains were found at the position of the 600-kDa α3 complexes. These results suggested that the 190-kDa α3 chain might exist as LN6 (α3β1γ1). The results also imply that the proteolytic processing of the laminin α3 chain occurs preferentially in LN5 in the HT1080/WT cells. The high-molecular weight aggregate of the α3 chain on the top of gel was not further investigated in this study. To characterize the 600-kDa complexes containing the laminin α3 chain, we attempted to isolate the laminin isoforms from the HT1080/WT conditioned medium. The conditioned medium was fractionated by the molecular-sieve chromatography, followed by the heparin affinity chromatography. Both the 190- and the 160-kDa α3 chains bound to the heparin column, but the former was eluted at 1.0 m NaCl, whereas the latter was mainly eluted at 0.5 m NaCl (data not shown). The difference in the affinity to heparin was consistent with our previous observation that the G4-5 fragment of the α3 chain tightly binds to a heparin column (13Tsubota Y. Mizushima H. Hirosaki T. Higashi S. Yasumitsu H. Miyazaki K. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 278: 614-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The eluted 190-kDa α3 chain was further purified by an anion-exchange HPLC and then passed through the anti-laminin γ2 antibody column to remove LN5. Finally, the material was bound to an immunoaffinity column conjugated with the anti-laminin α3 antibody and eluted therefrom. The purified material was analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting with five kinds of antibodies. The isolated protein migrated as a single band of about 600 kDa slightly beneath mouse LN1 under non-reducing conditions (Fig. 2 A). Reducing SDS-PAGE resolved the 600-kDa laminin into three bands with molecular masses of 220, 210, and 190 kDa (Fig. 2 B), and these bands were identified as the laminin β1, γ1, and α3 chains, respectively (Fig. 2 C). Neither anti-β3 nor anti-γ2 antibody reacted with any of the three chains (Fig. 2 C). These results indicate that the purified 600-kDa laminin is LN6. The LN5 purified by the immunoaffinity chromatography with the anti-laminin γ2 antibody contained only the 160-kDa form of the α3 chain, in addition to the 135-kDa β3 chain and the 150-/105-kDa γ2 chain (hereafter referred as mature LN5; mat-LN5) (Fig. 2, B andC). We also purified a small amount of LN6 with the 160-kDa α3 chain from the 0.5 m NaCl eluate from the heparin column. The 160-kDa α3 chain in this preparation was not reactive with the antibody against the G4 domain (data not shown). This indicated that the 160-kDa α3 chain had been cleaved between the G3 and G4 domains just like the 160-kDa α3 chain in mat-LN5. Therefore, we decided to purify this laminin at a higher yield from the conditioned medium of HT1080/ΔG4-5 cells, which had been transfected with the cDNA for the laminin α3 chain lacking both G4 and G5 domains (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). By the same purification procedure as above, a LN6 mutant, which lacked the G4 and G5 domains, was purified. This preparation, named LN6ΔG4-5, contained a 220-kDa β1 chain, a 210-kDa γ1 chain, and a 160-kDa α3 chain as analyzed by SDS-PAGE under reducing conditions (Fig. 2, Band C). Furthermore, we prepared a LN6 mutant, which lacked the G3, G4, and G5 domains, named LN6ΔG3-5, from the HT1080/ΔG3-5 cells (14Hirosaki T. Mizushima H. Tsubota Y. Moriyama K. Miyazaki K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 22495-22502Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). To characterize LN6, we compared some biological activities of the three forms of LN6 (LN6, LN6ΔG4-5, and LN6ΔG3-5), mat-LN5 and some other matrix proteins using three different cell lines: human keratinocyte cell line HaCaT, human fibrosarcoma cell line HT1080, and the rat liver cell line BRL. First, attachment of HaCaT cells was examined by inoculating these cells onto plastic plates precoated with different concentrations of the protein substrates (Fig.3 A). mat-LN5, LN6, and LN6ΔG4-5 efficiently supported the cell attachment, but LN6ΔG3-5 did hardly. Compared on a molar basis assuming a similar coating efficiency, the cell attachment activities of mat-LN5, LN6, and LN6ΔG4-5 were comparable, but higher than those of LN1, LN10/11, and fibronectin. The marked difference of the cell attachment activity between LN6ΔG4-5 and LN6ΔG3-5 suggests that the G3 domain is essential for the high affinity binding of LN6 to integrins. Essentially the same dose-response curves were obtained with HT1080 cells (data not shown). In the case of the BRL cells, LN6ΔG3-5 showed a cell attachment activity similar to those of LN1 and LN10/11 (Fig.3 B). Morphology of HaCaT cells on the different substrates was examined (Fig. 4, a–d). Despite the apparently similar cell attachment activity of mat-LN5, LN6, and LN6ΔG4-5, there was a marked morphological difference between the two LN6 forms. Rapid and extensive spreading of HaCaT cells was induced on mat-LN5 or LN6ΔG4-5, whereas on the LN-6 substrate they barely spread but exhibited some small spikes (or projections). HaCaT cells displayed more flattened morphology on LN10/11 than on mat-LN5 or LN6ΔG4-5. Poor cell spreading on LN6 was reproduced in HT1080 cells (Fig. 4,e–h) and BRL cells (data not shown). These results demonstrate that the proteolytic processing of laminin α3 chain converts LN6 from the inactive form to the active form regarding its cell spreading activity. To compare integrin requirement of mat-LN5 and two forms of LN6 (LN6 and LN6ΔG4-5), effects of function-blocking anti-integrin antibodies on the attachment of HaCaT cells were examined. The cell attachment activity of LN6 was completely blocked by the anti-integrin α3 or the anti-integrin β1 antibody (Fig.5 A). Almost the same results were obtained for LN6ΔG4-5 and mat-LN5 (data not shown). HaCaT cells are known to express both integrins α3β1and α6β4 (21Hintermann E. Bilban M. Sharabi A. Quaranta V. J. Cell Biol. 2001; 153: 465-478Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Therefore, our results imply that in HaCaT cells integrin α3β1 is the primary receptor for these laminins, and integrin α6β4 is not functional at least as the initial receptor. On the other hand, attachment of HT1080 cells to LN6 was partially blocked by the anti-integrin α3 antibody but completely by the anti-integrin β1 antibody or the anti-integrin α3 plus anti-integrin α6antibodies (Fig. 5 B). Essentially identical results were obtained for LN6ΔG4-5 and mat-LN5 (data not shown). Since HT1080 cells express integrins α3β1 and α6β1 but not integrin α6β4 (3Carter W.G. Ryan M.C. Gahr P.J. Cell. 1991; 65: 599-610Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (670) Google Scholar, 22Berditchevski F. Zutter M.M. Hemler M.E. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1996; 7: 193-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar), LN6, and LN6ΔG4-5, as well as mat-LN5, are thought to recognize both integrins α3β1 and α6β1. Integrin α6β1 may work as a secondary (or supplementary) receptor for these laminins. It is also noted that the presence or absence of the G4-5 domain in the α3 chain has practically no effect on the integrin binding specificity of LN6. LN5 is known to require a heat-sensitive helical conformation for the expression of the biological activity (5Miyazaki K. Kikkawa Y. Nakamura A. Yasumitsu H. Umeda M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 11767-11771Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 23Rousselle P. Golbik R. van der Rest M. Aumailley M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 13766-13770Abs

The inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (InsP3R) is a tetrameric assembly of conserved subunits that each contains six transmembrane regions (TMRs) localized near the carboxyl terminus. Receptor subunit assembly into a tetramer appears to be a multideterminant process involving an additive contribution of membrane spanning helices and the short cytosolic carboxyl terminus (residues 2590–2749). Previous studies have shown that of the six membrane-spanning regions in each subunit, the 5th and 6th transmembrane regions, and the carboxyl terminus are strong determinants for assembly. The fifth and sixth TMRs contain numerous β-branched amino acids that may participate in coiled/coil formation via putative leucine zipper motifs. InsP3R truncation mutants were expressed in COS-1 cells and analyzed by sucrose density gradient sedimentation and gel filtration for their ability to assemble. Chemical cross-linking with the homobifunctional reagents sDST or DMS of mammalian and bacterially expressed carboxyl-terminal containing receptor fragments reveals that sequences within the carboxyl terminus confer the formation of subunit dimers. A series of InsP3 receptor carboxyl-terminal fragments and glutathioneS-transferase (GST)/InsP3R chimeras were expressed in Escherichia coli and used in an in vitro assay to elucidate the minimal sequence responsible for association of the carboxyl termini into dimers. The results presented here indicate that this minimal sequence is ∼30 residues in length and is localized between residues 2629 and 2654. These residues are highly conserved between the three InsP3R isoforms (∼80% identity) as well as the ryanodine receptor (∼40% identity) and suggest that a conserved assembly motif may exist between the two intracellular receptor families. We propose that assembly of the InsP3 receptor to a tetramer involves intersubunit interactions mediated through both the membrane-spanning regions and residues 2629–2654 of the carboxyl terminus possibly through the formation of a dimer of dimers. The inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (InsP3R) is a tetrameric assembly of conserved subunits that each contains six transmembrane regions (TMRs) localized near the carboxyl terminus. Receptor subunit assembly into a tetramer appears to be a multideterminant process involving an additive contribution of membrane spanning helices and the short cytosolic carboxyl terminus (residues 2590–2749). Previous studies have shown that of the six membrane-spanning regions in each subunit, the 5th and 6th transmembrane regions, and the carboxyl terminus are strong determinants for assembly. The fifth and sixth TMRs contain numerous β-branched amino acids that may participate in coiled/coil formation via putative leucine zipper motifs. InsP3R truncation mutants were expressed in COS-1 cells and analyzed by sucrose density gradient sedimentation and gel filtration for their ability to assemble. Chemical cross-linking with the homobifunctional reagents sDST or DMS of mammalian and bacterially expressed carboxyl-terminal containing receptor fragments reveals that sequences within the carboxyl terminus confer the formation of subunit dimers. A series of InsP3 receptor carboxyl-terminal fragments and glutathioneS-transferase (GST)/InsP3R chimeras were expressed in Escherichia coli and used in an in vitro assay to elucidate the minimal sequence responsible for association of the carboxyl termini into dimers. The results presented here indicate that this minimal sequence is ∼30 residues in length and is localized between residues 2629 and 2654. These residues are highly conserved between the three InsP3R isoforms (∼80% identity) as well as the ryanodine receptor (∼40% identity) and suggest that a conserved assembly motif may exist between the two intracellular receptor families. We propose that assembly of the InsP3 receptor to a tetramer involves intersubunit interactions mediated through both the membrane-spanning regions and residues 2629–2654 of the carboxyl terminus possibly through the formation of a dimer of dimers. The second messenger inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (InsP3) 1The abbreviations used are: InsP3, d-myoinositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate; InsP3R, InsP3 receptor; TMR, transmembrane region; sDST, disulfosuccinimidyl tartrate; DMS, dimethyl suberimidate; GST, glutathione S-transferase; CHAPS, 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonic acid; FPLC, fast polynucleotide liquid chromatography; IPTG, isopropyl β-d-thiogalactoside; GFP, green fluorescent protein; RyR, ryanodine receptor; nt, nucleotide; Tricine, N-[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]glycine; FPLC, fast protein liquid chromatography. 1The abbreviations used are: InsP3, d-myoinositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate; InsP3R, InsP3 receptor; TMR, transmembrane region; sDST, disulfosuccinimidyl tartrate; DMS, dimethyl suberimidate; GST, glutathione S-transferase; CHAPS, 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonic acid; FPLC, fast polynucleotide liquid chromatography; IPTG, isopropyl β-d-thiogalactoside; GFP, green fluorescent protein; RyR, ryanodine receptor; nt, nucleotide; Tricine, N-[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]glycine; FPLC, fast protein liquid chromatography. occupies a crucial role in intracellular calcium signaling. InsP3 is generated through phosphoinositide turnover via the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate by phospholipase C in response to G protein or tyrosine kinase-coupled plasma membrane receptor stimulation. InsP3 rapidly diffuses to the endoplasmic reticulum and binds to the inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (InsP3R) inducing calcium release transients from intracellular stores. InsP3-mediated calcium signaling is implicated in numerous, diverse cellular processes including cell proliferation/differentiation, transcription, hepatic glycogen metabolism as well as learning and memory (1Berridge M.J. Lipp P. Bootman M.D. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 1: 11-21Google Scholar, 2Joseph S.K. Thomas A.P. Williams R.J. Irvine R.F. Williamson J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 3077-3081Google Scholar). The InsP3 receptor family is composed of at least three isoforms that share a high degree of sequence identity. The InsP3R protein is a tetrameric structure resulting from homo- or hetero-oligomerization of the receptor subunits. Each receptor subunit consists of an amino-terminal ligand binding domain of ∼600 amino acids containing many positively charged basic amino acids thought to participate in the ligand binding pocket (3Mignery G.A. Südhof T.C. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 3893-3898Google Scholar, 4Miyawaki A. Furuichi T. Ryou Y. Yoshikawa S. Nakagawa T. Saitoh T. Mikoshiba K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 4911-4915Google Scholar, 5Yoshikawa F. Morita M. Monkawa T. Michikawa T. Furuichi T. Mikoshiba K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 18277-18284Google Scholar). This region is highly conserved among the three isoforms yet the apparent affinity for InsP3 of each receptor subtype varies considerably (6Newton C.L. Mignery G.A. Südhof T.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 28613-28619Google Scholar). The central ∼1600 amino acids of the receptor is the least conserved region between the isoforms and has been coined the coupling or modulatory domain. This region has been proposed to couple or transduce ligand occupancy to channel opening through a conformational shift and contain numerous sequence motifs for potential modulation of the receptors function. These include modulatory phosphorylation sites as well as ATP, calcium, and calmodulin binding sites. The carboxyl-terminal ∼500 amino acids encode the calcium channel domain and include the six transmembrane-spanning segments. The ion permeation pathway is localized within the sequences encompassing the fifth and sixth transmembrane-spanning segments (7Ramos-Franco J. Galvan D. Mignery G.A. Fill M. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 243-250Google Scholar). The permeation properties of the three InsP3R isoforms intrinsic calcium channel are very similar. All channels exhibit similar calcium conductances and ionic selectivity. Despite these similarities, InsP3 and calcium differentially regulate the individual receptor isoforms (8Ramos-Franco J. Fill M. Mignery G.A. Biophys. J. 1998; 75: 834-839Google Scholar, 9Hagar R.E. Burgstahler A.D. Nathanson M.H. Ehrlich B.E. Nature. 1998; 396: 81-84Google Scholar, 10Mak D.D. McBride S. Foskett J.K. J. Gen. Physiol. 2001; 117: 435-446Google Scholar). These properties likely account for the heterogeneity in calcium signaling observed in cells expressing more than one isoform of the receptor. In addition to forming the calcium channel, the membrane-spanning sequences are key elements that contribute to receptor subunit assembly into tetramers (3Mignery G.A. Südhof T.C. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 3893-3898Google Scholar, 11Joseph S.K. Boehning D. Pierson S. Nicchitta C.V. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1579-1588Google Scholar, 12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). In particular, the fifth and sixth transmembrane regions are critical determinants for oligomerization (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). A plasmid encoding an InsP3R construction in which the first four membrane-spanning sequences were deleted assembled into tetramers and when characterized electrophysiologically, the recombinant protein formed nearly constitutively open calcium channels (7Ramos-Franco J. Galvan D. Mignery G.A. Fill M. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 243-250Google Scholar). These had very similar permeation properties to those of the wild type receptor. The fifth and sixth membrane-spanning regions ability to form stable oligomers has been proposed to be a consequence of interactions mediated by β-branched amino acid residues, which resemble a leucine zipper motif (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). Another sequence region identified as critical for oligomerization of the receptor subunits is the cytosolic 160 carboxyl-terminal amino acids. These residues significantly enhance receptor assembly into high apparent molecular weight oligomers (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). This enhanced assembly was observed with protein contexts containing as few as two transmembrane-spanning regions through constructions containing all six (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). In addition to receptor subunit assembly, the carboxyl-terminal region has been implicated in interactions with the amino-terminal ligand binding domain and possibly contributes to channel activity (13Boehning D. Joseph S.K. EMBO J. 2000; 19: 5450-5459Google Scholar, 14Nakade S. Maeda N. Mikoshiba K. Biochem. J. 1991; 277: 125-131Google Scholar, 15Miyazaki S.I. Yuzaki M. Nakade S. Shirakawa H. Nakanishi S. Nakade S. Mikoshiba K. Science. 1992; 257: 251-255Google Scholar). A notable feature of this region of the InsP3R protein family is the high degree of homology with the ryanodine receptor. In this study we investigated the role of the cytosolic carboxyl-terminal amino acids in the assembly and oligomerization of the InsP3R into functional tetramers. Receptor mammalian expression construct series containing exclusively the 5th, 6th as well as sequences encompassed by both membrane-spanning sequences with progressively truncated carboxyl termini were characterized for their ability to oligomerize using sucrose density gradient sedimentation and size exclusion chromatography. In addition, a series of bacterial expression products derived from the cytosolic carboxyl terminus were used in GST pull-downs and chemical cross-linking experiments to localize potential interactions. These studies reveal that a sequence region of ∼30 amino acids, spanning residues 2629–2654, in the carboxyl terminus confers the formation of subunit dimers and are essential for receptor assembly. All other chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. A series of plasmid intermediates containing the type-1 InsP3R transmembrane regions (TMR) 5 and 6 and sequences encompassing 5–6 were prepared in pGEM3Z. pGem3Z was modified by inserting annealed GM123-AATTCTTCGAAGCGGGAAGATCTG/GM124-GATCCAGATCTTCCCGC TTCGAAG into theEcoRI/BamHI-digested vector, introducing uniqueBstBI and BglII sites. Fragments corresponding to fifth, sixth, and fifth through sixth TMRs were generated by PCR. The PCR primers used to generate the TMR sequences were as follows: TMR5, GM018-GCGCCATGGTTCGAAGTGTCACCCGCAATGGACGGCCC (nt 7622–7645) and GM016-ACTAGTCGACGAGATCTTGGTCTTGTTCAAGATAAAGTCATCCTT (nt 7716–7732); TMR6, GM143-GCGCCATGGTTCGAAGGGTGATCTATGAC (nt 8021–8035) and GM002-GTCAAGCTTGTCCCT(T/C)TCCAAGCC(G/A)CAGATGAAGCA (nt 8157–8192); TMRs5–6, GM018 (nt 7622–7645) and GM002 (nt 8157–8192). To these intermediate plasmids, various fragments of the type 1 InsP3R carboxyl terminus were added. Biol. The creation of the carboxyl-terminal deletion series (-40, -60, -80, -100, -120, and -144 amino acids) was achieved by insertingBglII/XbaI-digested PCR amplification products into similarly digested pGEMTMR intermediates. The 3′ antisense primers contained the termination codon and were as follows: -40C, GM144-CGGAATTCTAGAGTTAGGTGACCAGCTTC, nt 8444–8456; -60C, GM145-CGGAATTCTAGAGTTACCCTTCAGAGTCAC, nt 8383–8396; -80C, GM146-CGGAATTCTAGAGTTATCTTTCCCTGATC, nt 8324–8336; -100C, GM147-CGGAATTCTAGAGTTACACTTTCACCAG, nt 8265–8276; -120C, GM148-CGGAATTCTAGAGTTACTCTTCAAAGGTG, nt 8204–8216); and -144C, GM149-CGGAATTCTAGAGTTAGATCTCTTCCTTC, nt 8132–8144. This process resulted in a pGEM-3Z-based vector series encoding TMR 5, 6, or 5–6 with a sequentially greater truncation of the carboxyl terminus (pGEMTMRX-40, -60, -80, -100, -120, and -144). Newton C.L. Archer III B.T. Südhof T.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 12679-12685Google Scholar, 17Ramos-Franco J. Caenepeel S. Fill M. Mignery G.A. Biophys. J. 1998; 75: 2783-2793Google Scholar). This resulted in the final series of pTMR5-XC, pTMR6-XC, and pTMR5–6-XC expression constructs (Fig. 2). The amino-terminally truncated series of mammalian expression vectors were prepared using a similar strategy, except that plasmid pCMVI-11 was used as a host vector. This plasmid is missing the 418 amino-terminal amino acid residues, tetramerizes, and does not bind InsP3 (16Mignery G.A. Newton C.L. Archer III B.T. Südhof T.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 12679-12685Google Scholar). Frozen rabbit heart ventricle (1 gram) was ground to a powder in liquid nitrogen and solubilized with GTC (4m guanidinium thiocyanate, 20 mm sodium acetate, 1% 2-mercaptoethanol, 0.1 m dithiothreitol, 0.5% sarkosyl). The sample was clarified by 15 min, 3220 ×g, 20 °C centrifugation. The resulting supernatant was layered on top of a 5.7 m cesium chloride cushion and centrifuged for 16 h at 26,700 rpm, 20 °C in a SW41 rotor. The total RNA pellet was allowed to air dry and dissolved in nuclease-free water, precipitated, and quantitated. 5 μg of the total RNA was used as a template for first strand cDNA synthesis. Each 50-μl reaction contained 500 μm dNTPs (Amersham Biosciences), 20 units of RNase inhibitor (Promega), 1 μg of pd(N)6 random hexamer (Amersham Biosciences) in 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.3, 75 mm KCl, 3 mm MgCl2, 10 mm dithiothreitol plus 200–400 units of Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase (Invitrogen). Reactions were incubated at 37 °C for 60 min and heat-inactivated for 5 min at 95 °C. The RyR carboxyl-terminal clone was built in modified pET-8C. Oligonucleotides GM230-GATCCTGCAGAGCTTCGAACACATCCGCGAGGGCAAGTTCGACGAGTAG and GM231-GATCCTACTCGTCGAACTTGCCCTCGCGGATGTGTTCGAAGCTCTGCAG were annealed and inserted into BamHI-digested pET-8C to introduce aBstBI site followed by the coding sequence for the final 11 residues of the 116-kDa subunit of the proton pump. Next the reverse-transcribed RNA from rabbit heart ventricle was used as a template for PCR with the primer pair GM232-CATGCCATGGGATCCGATGCTTTTGGAGAACTCAGAGACC (nt 14918–14942) and GM233-GGAATTCGAAATTTAGCTGGTCTTCATACTGTTTCCGG (nt 15190–15218) to amplify the DNA encoding the final 100 residues of the RyR-2 carboxyl terminus. Modified vector and PCR products were digested withBstBI/NcoI and ligated together to generate pETR4870–4969. The identity of the pETR4870–4969 was confirmed by DNA sequencing. COS-1 cells were transiently transfected with InsP3R plasmid DNA using the DEAE-dextran method (19Gorman C. Glover D.M. DNA cloning. II. IRL Press, Oxford1985: 143-190Google Scholar). Cells were incubated at 37 °C, 5% CO2 for 48–72 h prior to harvesting for analysis. Transfected COS-1 cells were harvested 48–72 h post-transfection. Cells were washed twice in phosphate-buffered saline and harvested by scraping into 50 mm Tris (pH 8.3), 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm 2-mercaptoethanol, and 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Cells were lysed by 20 passages through a 27.5-gauge needle. Microsomal fractions were pelleted by centrifugation at 4 °C for 10 min at (106,120 × g). Microsomes were resuspended in buffer and solubilized by adjusting the buffer to 1% CHAPS and mixing on ice for 1–2 h. Prior to oligomerization analysis, the solubilized samples had the insoluble fraction removed by centrifugation at 4 °C for 10 min at (106,120 × g) two times followed by passage through a 0.22-μm cellulose-acetate Spin-X centrifuge filter (Corning; Corning, NY). Sucrose gradients were run as previously described (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). Essentially, 2 ml of 5–20% continuous sucrose gradients were centrifuged for 4 h and 55 min, 4 °C, at 166,320 × g in a Beckman TLS-55 swinging bucket rotor. Gradients were subsequently fractionated into 25 × 80-μl aliquots, and InsP3R protein was detected by immunoblotting. FPLC analyses were performed with anAmersham Biosciences AB Superose 6 HR 10/30 column. The mobile phase was 1% CHAPS, 150 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris (pH 8.3), 1 mm EDTA, and 1 mm 2-mercaptoethanol and run at 0.4 ml/min. The column eluates were fractionated into 0.25-ml aliquots. BL21-CodonPlus Competent Cells (Stratagene) harboring the InsP3R plasmids were cultured overnight in Luria Broth + 50 μg/ml chloramphenicol + 100 μg/ml ampicillin. The culture was diluted and then incubated at 37 °C until reaching an optical density (λ, 600 nm) of 0.7. IPTG was added to a final concentration of 1 mm, and cells were incubated for an additional 3–4 h. Cells were pelleted at 4 °C for 20 min at (48,000 × g). Cell pellets were scraped into liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 °C until further use. Frozen bacterial cell pellets were weighed out, and lysis buffer was added STET (8% sucrose, 0.5% Triton X-100, 10 mm Tris-CL, pH 8.0, 50 mmEDTA, 0.25% lysozyme, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and incubated with shaking at ambient temperature for 20 min. Samples were sonicated 2 × 30 s and the DNase and RNase A added to 4 μg/ml and 10 μg/ml, respectively. Samples were incubated at ambient temperature for 30 min after the addition with shaking. Samples centrifuged at 4 °C for 15 min at (15,000 × g), and supernatants were decanted. Pellets were washed three times in Wash Buffer (0.5 m NaCl, 0.5% Triton X-100, 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and a final wash in 0.1 mTris-CL (pH 8.5), 1 m urea, 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. The final pellet was resuspended in ice-cold water and frozen at −80 °C. Bacterial expression products were solubilized in 8 m urea, 150 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris (pH 7.4), 3 mm 2-mercaptoethanol, and 3 mm dithiothreitol. Following solubilization, the samples were centrifuged at 4 °C for 10 min at (106,120 ×g). Pellets were discarded, and the solubilized protein was subjected to dialysis against 4 × 1000 volumes of 150 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris (pH 7.4), 1 mm2-mercaptoethanol. Recovered dialysates were centrifuged at 4 °C for 10 min at (106,120 × g) to remove the insoluble fraction and ∼25% of each sample removed for SDS/PAGE, followed by Coomassie Blue staining to identify the initial starting material. The remainder of the sample was interacted with glutathione-Sepharose MicroSpin GST Purification Module mini-columns (Amersham Biosciences). Columns were washed 3 × 0.5 ml with the above dialysis buffer. Bound material was eluted with 10 mm reduced glutathione. Eluted material was run on SDS/PAGE and Coomassie-stained to reveal eluted proteins. COS cell expression products were resolved on 5% SDS/PAGE with the exception of the chemically cross-linked material, which was resolved on 4% SDS/PAGE. Bacterially expressed proteins were run on 14% SDS/PAGE and Tris/Tricine SDS-polyacrylamide gels (20Schagger H. Von-Jagow G. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 166: 368-379Google Scholar). The Tris/Tricine resolving gels were 16.5%T/3%C with and without 10%T/3%C spacer gels and a 4%T/3%C stacking gel. Gels were either stained with Coomassie Blue or immunoblotted using chemiluminescent reagents (AmershamBiosciences). The InsP3R-specific amino-terminal (T1NH) and carboxyl-terminal (T1C) polyclonal antibodies were generated against residues 308–326 of the type-1 SIb alternatively spliced isoform and the 19 carboxyl-terminal amino acids, respectively (17Ramos-Franco J. Caenepeel S. Fill M. Mignery G.A. Biophys. J. 1998; 75: 2783-2793Google Scholar). The luminal loop antipeptide antibody (V753) is directed against residues 2463–2476 of the type-1 receptor. The proton pump tag antibody is directed against the 11 carboxyl-terminal residues of the 116-kDa subunit of the proton pump (3Mignery G.A. Südhof T.C. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 3893-3898Google Scholar, 12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). An additional peptide antibody, B188, was used in Western blotting and is directed against residues 2607–2623 of the type-1 InsP3R. All InsP3R peptide antibodies were affinity-purified using immunogenic peptide. The GST antibody was purchased from Affinity Bioreagents, Inc. The secondary antibody used was a horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit antibody. Solubilized protein was chemically cross-linked with either sulfo-disuccinimidyl tartrate (sDST) or dimethyl suberimidate (DMS). Final reactions had various millimolar amounts of freshly prepared cross-linking reagent added to 0.25 mg/ml solubilized protein, 200 mm HEPES (pH 8.0), 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm 2-mercaptoethanol. Reactions were incubated at ambient temperature for 45 min and then quenched with the addition of 4× SDS/PAGE sample buffer. Samples were immediately boiled and run on SDS/PAGE, followed by immunoblotting. It is well established that the multiple membrane-spanning sequences of the InsP3R subunits are essential determinants for the targeting, assembly, and formation of the intrinsic calcium release channel (3Mignery G.A. Südhof T.C. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 3893-3898Google Scholar, 7Ramos-Franco J. Galvan D. Mignery G.A. Fill M. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 243-250Google Scholar, 12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar, 21Otsu K. Willard H.F. Khanna V.K. Zorzato F. Green N.M. MacLennan D.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 13472-13483Google Scholar). The 5th and 6th membrane-spanning sequences, which together with the interceding luminal loop constitute the channel pore, are efficiently assembled into tetramers in the presence of the cytoplasmic carboxyl termini. Previously, Galvanet al. (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar) demonstrated that the inclusion of the carboxyl terminus with membrane-spanning region deletions augmented receptor subunit assembly into oligomers. The apparently additive affect of the carboxyl terminus was observed with recombinant protein containing as few as two through those containing all six membrane-spanning regions (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar). In addition, yeast two-hybrid experiments using the cytoplasmic carboxyl-terminal fragment indicated a potential interaction between the termini. In support of these observations, Magnino et al. (22Magnino F. Schmidt K. Mery L. Dufour J.F. Eur. J. Biochem. 2001; 268: 5981-5988Google Scholar) reported similar observations using the type-2 InsP3R. In a previous study (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar) we noted that the inclusion of the cytoplasmic carboxyl terminus enhanced InsP3R membrane-spanning region truncation expression product assembly. This enhancement was observed in all contexts of membrane-spanning regions containing as few as two and as many as all six and resulted in a substantial shift of expression products to more dense regions of the sucrose gradients. The effect of the receptor carboxyl terminus upon the assembly of the InsP3R containing the full complement of membrane-spanning sequences is illustrated in Fig. 1. In this series of immunoblots the full-length (pInsP3R-T1, TMR1–6+C) and a carboxyl-terminally truncated receptor (TMR1–6-C) were sedimented through 5–20% sucrose gradients either independently or as mixed samples. The expression products of the protein lacking the carboxyl termini sedimented with a distinct high density component yet, as previously observed (12Galvan D. Borrego-Diaz E. Perez P.J. Mignery G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29483-29492Google Scholar), there was a substantial amount of material that did not sediment to density gradient positions consistent with a high

During clathrin-mediated endocytosis Hsc70, supported by the J-domain protein auxilin, uncoats clathrin-coated vesicles. Auxilin contains both a clathrin-binding domain and a J-domain that binds Hsc70, and it has been suggested that these two domains are both necessary and sufficient for auxilin activity. To test this hypothesis, we created a chimeric protein consisting of the J-domain of auxilin linked to the clathrin-binding domain of the assembly protein AP180. This chimera supported uncoating, but unlike auxilin it acted stoichiometrically rather than catalytically because, like Hsc70, it remained associated with the uncoated clathrin. This observation supports our proposal that Hsc70 chaperones uncoated clathrin by inducing formation of a stable Hsc70-clathrin-AP complex. It also shows that Hsc70 acts by dissociating individual clathrin triskelions rather than cooperatively destabilizing clathrin-coated vesicles. Because the chimera lacks the C-terminal subdomain of the auxilin clathrin-binding domain, it seemed possible that this subdomain is required for auxilin to act catalytically, and indeed its deletion caused auxilin to act stoichiometrically. In contrast, deletion of the N-terminal subdomain weakened auxilin-clathrin binding and prevented auxilin from polymerizing clathrin. Therefore the C-terminal subdomain of the clathrin-binding domain of auxilin is required for auxilin to act catalytically, whereas the N-terminal subdomain strengthens auxilin-clathrin binding. During clathrin-mediated endocytosis Hsc70, supported by the J-domain protein auxilin, uncoats clathrin-coated vesicles. Auxilin contains both a clathrin-binding domain and a J-domain that binds Hsc70, and it has been suggested that these two domains are both necessary and sufficient for auxilin activity. To test this hypothesis, we created a chimeric protein consisting of the J-domain of auxilin linked to the clathrin-binding domain of the assembly protein AP180. This chimera supported uncoating, but unlike auxilin it acted stoichiometrically rather than catalytically because, like Hsc70, it remained associated with the uncoated clathrin. This observation supports our proposal that Hsc70 chaperones uncoated clathrin by inducing formation of a stable Hsc70-clathrin-AP complex. It also shows that Hsc70 acts by dissociating individual clathrin triskelions rather than cooperatively destabilizing clathrin-coated vesicles. Because the chimera lacks the C-terminal subdomain of the auxilin clathrin-binding domain, it seemed possible that this subdomain is required for auxilin to act catalytically, and indeed its deletion caused auxilin to act stoichiometrically. In contrast, deletion of the N-terminal subdomain weakened auxilin-clathrin binding and prevented auxilin from polymerizing clathrin. Therefore the C-terminal subdomain of the clathrin-binding domain of auxilin is required for auxilin to act catalytically, whereas the N-terminal subdomain strengthens auxilin-clathrin binding. Eisenberg E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23758-23761Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar); the J-domain protein auxilin must also be present in catalytic amounts (4Ungewickell E. Ungewickell H. Holstein S.E. Lindner R. Prasad K. Barouch W. Martin B. Greene L.E. Eisenberg E. Nature. 1995; 378: 632-635Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). Furthermore, knockout of auxilin in yeast or knockdown of auxilin in Caenorhabditis elegans prevents endocytosis from taking place (5Pishvaee B. Costaguta G. Yeung B.G. Ryazantsev S. Greener T. Greene L.E. Eisenberg E. McCaffery J.M. Payne G.S. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 958-963Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 6Gall W.E. Higginbotham M.A. Chen C. Ingram M.F. Cyr D.M. Graham T.R. J-domain proteins are thought to function by inducing substrates to bind to Hsc70, and this has been directly demonstrated for auxilin by showing that auxilin is required for ATP-dependent binding of Hsc70 at pH 6, where there is no uncoating (8Barouch W. Prasad K. Greene L. Eisenberg E. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 4303-4308Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Although the mechanism of action of J-domain proteins is not completely understood, it is generally thought that they first bind substrate and then transfer the substrate to Hsc70-ATP and, finally, induce one round of rapid ATP hydrolysis by Hsc70 (9King C. Eisenberg E. Greene L.E. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12452-12459Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 10Cheetham M.E. Caplan A.J. Cell Stress. Chaperones. 1998; 3: 28-36Crossref PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar). This stabilizes the binding of substrate because most substrates detach rapidly from Hsc70-ATP but very slowly from Hsc70-ADP (11Zhu X. Zhao X. Burkholder W.F. Gragerov A. Ogata C.M. Gottesman M.E. Hendrickson W.A. Science. 1996; 272: 1606-1614Crossref PubMed Scopus (1064) Google Scholar, 12Palleros D.R. Reid K.L. Shi L. Welch W.J. Fink A.L. Chem. 1994; 269: 6931-6939Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To carry out their function J-domain proteins must contain both a J-domain that interacts with Hsc70 and a substrate-binding domain that interacts with substrate. In fact, mammalian auxilin, a multi-domain protein, consists of at least three domains, an N-terminal Pten-like domain (15Haynie D.T. Ponting C.P. Protein Sci. 1996; 5: 2643-2646Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar) of unknown function, a clathrin-binding domain, and a C-terminal J-domain (4Ungewickell E. Ungewickell H. Holstein S.E. Lindner R. Prasad K. Barouch W. Martin B. Greene L.E. Eisenberg E. Nature. 1995; 378: 632-635Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). In addition to these domains there is a kinase domain in the ubiquitously expressed form of auxilin called GAK (16Greener T. Zhao X. Nojima H. Eisenberg E. Greene L.E. J. Biol.
